events.title: Pakistan Floods, Spring/Summer 2015
events.description: Heavy rainfall has resulted in flash flooding in northern and central Pakistan from the early spring through the monsoon in July and August.

items.title: PAKISTAN FLOODS
items.description:
The recent disastrous floods in Pakistan have rendered 15,000,000 people homeless. The United States gave immediate aid to the stricken people of Pakistan in the form of food and medical supplies.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/529bd8a2876d41be8c3f289a84705d21 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Pakistan Navy rescues hundreds of people marooned by floods
items.description:
SHOTLIST
++NIGHT SHOTS++
1. Wide of PNS Tariq, a rescue ship of Pakistani navy 
2. Pakistani flag flying on Pakistani navy ship 
3. Various of navy servicemen placing walkway onto ship 
4. Pakistani soldiers bringing injured on stretchers from ship
5. Injured man being placed in ambulance 
6. Ambulance driving away
7. Various of survivors getting off ship 
8. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Zulfiqar Ali, flood survivor:
"We were trapped on the Angora bridge.  We were stranded there for two days.  Then the navy was informed, which brought us to Ormara.  They really helped us and finally brought us to Karachi."
9. Various of survivors walking from ship
10. PNS Tariq banner on walkway
11. SOUNDBITE: (English) Captain Mazhar (no first name given), Pakistani navy official:
"Today 265 people, we have evacuated them from Ormara.  They were stranded there and they were in need obviously to be lifted and taken out of that area so we have brought them to here in Karachi and we have despatched them to their respective houses wherever they require."
12. Photographer taking photo
STORYLINE: 
Pakistani troops and rescue workers continued their struggle on Sunday, to help 1.3 (m) million victims of monsoon-triggered floods in the country's southwest.
On Sunday 265 people arrived in Karachi aboard the PNS Tariq, a ship of the Pakistani navy.
A Pakistani navy official said that the people had been been rescued from Ormara and other coastal areas of Baluchistan.
"They were stranded there and they were in need obviously to be lifted and taken out of that area so we have brought them to here in Karachi and we have despatched them to their respective houses," Captain Mazhar said.
Zulfiqar Ali, a flood survivor said he and others were trapped on the Angora bridge.
"We were stranded there for two days.  Then the navy was informed, which brought us to Ormara.  They really helped us and finally brought us to Karachi," Ali said.
Earlier 122 people including women, children and elders, were brought to Karachi.
The floods have left as many as 100 people dead in southwestern Pakistan, a senior relief official said on Sunday, as the government appealed for donations of tents to shelter about one million people left homeless by the flooding.
The deaths have occurred in the southwestern province of Baluchistan since Tuesday, when Cyclone Yemyin and rains triggered floods across a vast area, said Tariq Ayub, Baluchistan's home secretary, who is overseeing the flood relief operation.
Authorities said many of the casualties occurred due to drowning and people getting trapped under the debris of their collapsing homes.
With roads washed away by the flood waters leaving hundreds of villages cut off by swollen rivers, army helicopters have been flying over the affected areas and dropping tents, food and clean water to stranded villagers.
But more heavy rains are expected in the normally arid areas around coastal town of Turbat, about 650 kilometres (400 miles) southeast of Quetta, leaving rescue workers in a race against time to get as much aid to victims as possible before they are cut off by floods once again. 
Workers from local welfare group, the Edhi Foundation, have formed mobile kitchens and tour villages supplying the hot meals and clean water. 
Villagers elsewhere said they were still waiting for aid to arrive.
Officials have said a large number of people in Baluchistan's flood-hit area had no access to safe drinking water, raising the possibility of waterborne diseases. 
A Pakistani Navy spokesperson told reporters that rescue and relief operations were underway along the coastal belts of the Balochistan. 
He said the PNS Kalimaat, carrying food aid, had reached Ormara and two medical camps were being set up in Gawadar and Pasni. 


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/98494ef009fca9b6e355be9ad6bddfb8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Aid arrives in remote area affected by floods
items.description:
1. Wide of Pakistan army personnel and civilians loading helicopter with aid for flood victims 
2. Mid of people unloading relief goods from truck 
3. Close of boxes of medical aid labelled 'UNICEF', (the United Nations Children's Fund)
4. Wide of people loading medicine boxes onto helicopter
5. Aerial of flooding in Nasirabad district, Baluchistan, one area hardest hit by flooding
6. Soldiers dropping aid to victims
7. Flood victims approaching helicopters to receive aid; group tussle over relief goods
8. Paramilitary security forces keeping crowd away from helicopter 
9. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Major Shahid Saeed, helicopter pilot: 
"Today we are dropping our medical teams in different places like Nasirabad and Alumdar. In the mornings we drop the teams and in the afternoon we come and pick them up again and take them back to base. We are dropping relief goods like food stuffs, medicines, tents, mineral water, lots of it all. Everyday we are trying to solve this problem."
10. Aerial of crowd of homeless people from Nasirabad district
STORYLINE:
Pakistan called on the international community to rush aid to some one (m) million people left homeless by massive flooding amid forecasts on Monday that still more rain would be dumped on the stricken areas in coming days.
Floods due to a cyclone and rain since 23 June have left as many as 211 people dead in two provinces of southern Pakistan, a senior relief official said on Monday, but unofficial estimates are considerably higher.
Some 500 people have died across the subcontinent, in Pakistan, India and Afghanistan, since the start of the monsoon season in early June.
Following a two-day tour of the flooded area on Sunday, Pakistan Prime Minister Shaukat Aziz asked for relief and rehabilitation aid from foreign countries, international agencies and private donors.
He said more helicopters would be added to army efforts to ferry food, medicine and other relief supplies to areas of Baluchistan province which was hit by Cyclone Yemyin last Tuesday.
In Nasirabad, 50 kilometres (31 miles) west of Turbat, Baluchistan on Monday, aid was seen being loaded onto helicopters and dropped into the region. 
"Today we are dropping our medical teams in different places like Nasirabad and Alumdar. In the mornings we drop the teams and in the afternoon we come and pick them up again and take them back to base. We are dropping relief goods like food stuffs, medicines, tents, mineral water, lots of it," said Major Shahid Saeed, a pilot from one of the helicopters delivering aid to the victims. 
The military said Pakistani and Chinese engineers had reopened the Karakoram Highway, which runs between the two countries. 
The road link was severed by heavy, rain-spawned landslides near the 4,733-metre (15,528-feet) Khunjrab Pass.
In the Baluchistan city of Turbat, one of the worst-affected areas, doctors reported an influx of patients, many of them children, suffering from nausea, diarrhoea and other water-borne diseases.
The flooding has also spread in recent days into adjacent Sindh province to the east, where some 200-thousand people were rendered homeless in Shahdad Kot district after waters from a canal spilled over protective embankments, provincial relief commissioner Munir Ahmed said on Monday.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/d5da848e25fc7de5d4e4d8e67c8f7c34 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: VOICED: More Afghan refugees flood into Pakistan
items.description:
VOICED BY: Vera Frankl
TOKO Pictures
0000 Wide shot of border crossing point
0005 Border sign
0008 Women and children arriving
0012 Mid shot of vehicles
0015 Close up of boy driving off in truck
0020 SOUNDBITE: (Pashtu) Gulbaran, Refugee from Kandahar
"There was continuous bombardment, there was bombardment in the morning and this bombardment was not against the military bases, it was on civilian vehicles, it caused a lot of damage and the people were badly wounded and they were rushed to the hospital immediately."
0034 Women and children arrive
0039 Refugees getting on to back of truck
0043 Rear shot of people crossing border
0048 Mid shot of vehicles

STORYLINE

Afghan refugees continue to cross the border into Pakistan.

Many of them have come from the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar and say they were escaping US attacks.

All of those crossing had valid documents for entering Pakistan. 

It is not known how many remain on the Afghan side of the border, without documentation.

Some of those crossing were headed to stay with relatives, others went to refugee camps.

0001 More refugees from Afghanistan poured across the border into Pakistan on Wednesday. At least a thousand crossed at Chaman, on the border between Afghanistan and the southwestern Pakistani province of Baluchistan.
Many came from the Taliban stronghold of Kandahar and said they were fleeing American bombs.

0020 "There was continuous bombardment," this man said, "and it wasn't against the military bases - it was on civilian vehicles. It caused a lot of damage and the people were badly wounded and rushed to hospital," this man said.

0034 The refugees who have managed to make their way to Pakistan may also be escaping starvation in their homeland. International aid groups say there must be a pause in the bombing so they can deliver 50 thousand tons of food to help Afghan civilians survive the harsh winter months.

ENDS 0053


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/47b26968fa7c2fb593e4bc7984164255 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: More rain expected for flood hit Pakistan
items.description:
For more WORLD NEWS "SUBSCRIBE" US

More rain is forecast in north Pakistan after flash floods inundated several villages in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan provinces.
At least three people have died, Pakistani media reported, and hundreds of thousands have been displaced.

Every year, monsoon rains trigger floods in Pakistan killing scores of people.

Chitral in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa was among the worst affected, with major damage to buildings.
The provincial information minister, Mushtaq Ghani, told reporters that upper parts of the city were cut off, stranding about 200,00 people, according to Dawn newspaper.

items.title: 12 more dead in Pakistan Floods
items.description:
For more WORLD NEWS "SUBSCRIBE" US

Pakistani authorities say flash floods, triggered by monsoon rains, have killed 12 more people across the country, bringing the overall death toll since early last week to 15, as rescuers struggle to move those stranded to safer places.

Friday’s statement by the National Disaster Management Authority says seven of the deaths were reported in flood-hit areas in the southwestern Baluchistan province while three people died in the eastern Punjab province. Flood waters also killed two people in the northern Gilgit Baltistan region. It says 194,137 people in the district of Layyah and other regions in the eastern Punjab province have been affected. Meanwhile, the situation was returning to normalcy in the northern city of Chitral, where floods earlier this week killed three people and destroyed roads and bridges

items.title: Latest from Dadu where hundreds were evacuated after more flooding
items.description:
1. Aerial of Dadu district showing flood ed  houses and huts
2. Pakistan naval official looking out of helicopter
3. Pakistan naval official unloading medicines from helicopter in Faridabad village, Dadu district 
4. Flood victims including children, women and men approaching helicopter to be lifted to safer place 
5. Flood victims boarding helicopter 
6. Flood victims running towards helicopter 
7. Flood victims sitting inside helicopter with children 
8. Close  of children
9. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Naheed (only name given), flood victim,
"In our village Faridabad, poor people are just waiting for help as there is nothing available to eat or drink. There are some rare food supplies from a boat. No flour or vegetables. Nothing is available in the village."
10. Pakistan naval official helping children to climb from helicopter 
11. Naval official carrying old man from helicopter
12. Wide of helicopter 
13. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Commander Jawad Khawjanavy, Naval Officer
"We are covering the Faridabad area through helicopter and hovercraft. Our helicopters are performing a dual task. First it flies with food supplies, and then it rescues the stranded people. For the past week we have been evacuating people from different villages and towns. We lift approximately 150 flood victims each day."
14. Wide shot, makeshift camps in a college in Dadu district 
15. Old man with crutches sitting in tent
16. Close  of children
17. People sitting in tent 
18. Child sleeping in tent
19. Mid  of tents
STORYLINE:
The ongoing floods in southern Pakistan's Sindh province are continuing to affect new areas. 
The UN humanitarian affairs office reported new flooding around the town of Dadu on Wednesday, near the Indus River in Sindh province, about 200 miles (330 kilometres) from the Arabian Sea.
The Pakistani Army meanwhile continued with relief efforts, rescuing hundreds of people in Dadu District trapped or isolated by floodwaters.
Flood-related health problems continued to increase despite receding waters in many parts of the country. 
The World Health Organisation reported a spike in suspected malaria cases in Sindh and Baluchistan provinces, while diarrhoea and acute respiratory diseases such as pneumonia continue to plague the disaster zone. 
More than 4.5 (m) million people have received medical help since the flooding began in late July.
Between 600-thousand and 800-thousand people have been displaced over the past four days and three towns remain under water. 
About 150-thousand people were waiting on a road for assistance, according to what the UN described as rough estimates from staff and local officials in the area.
At least 3.5 (m) million people in Sindh and 6.5 (m) million nationwide have been displaced. 
The flooding began with unusually heavy rains in the country's northern mountains and killed more than 1,600 people. 
Millions have been driven from their homes and the waters are still swamping rich agricultural land in the southern provinces of Sindh and Punjab.
Pakistan's weak civilian government is struggling to deal with the massive flooding which began with unusually heavy rains in the country's northern mountains and killed more than 1,600 people.
According to the United Nations the disaster has affected more than 17 (m) million people. 
The flooding that swamped as much as one-fifth of the country destroyed 3.6 (m) million hectares (8.9 (m) million acres) of maize, rice, sugar cane and cotton crops and killed 1.2 (m) million livestock and 6 (m) million poultry, according to preliminary estimates by the UN and the government.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/0a2be3f0b7b1bfecfaf8132c261aa601 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Minister on Taliban threat against aid workers, new floods
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of news conference 
2. Reporters in audience
3. Mid of news conference 
4. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Qamar Zaman Kaira, Pakistan information minister: 
"The lower areas of Sindh province will remain under floodwater for the next two weeks or more. Our brothers and sisters who live there face this difficult situation. You may all know, that the embankment which was around the outskirts of Thatta has broken and it creates difficulties. Some people are being evacuated from there." 
5. Wide of news conference
6. SOUNDBITE: (English) Qamar Zaman Kaira, Pakistan information minister:
"The Taliban are basically threatening the whole nation, the whole world. In these circumstances, they believe that in these miserable conditions and in this very acute disturbed problem in Pakistan, in this very difficult situation, if the world come to rescue Pakistan and the Pakistani people come to rescue the affected people, then they can come out of this mess, sir. And if this mess goes on, then this is in their benefit, this is in the benefit of all those who are against the interests and against the peace of Pakistan and the region and the world. So they will threaten the people but their capacity and capability is now not that much. And whosoever, the aid workers, health workers who have come here, federal agencies and the provincial agencies, like police and others, as well, we will provide them proper security."
7. Wide of news conference ending
STORYLINE
Pakistan's government vowed on Friday to protect foreign aid workers against attacks from the Taliban, who have issued a veiled threat against relief organisations helping out in the country's flooding crisis. 
The comments came as hundreds of thousands of people fled floodwaters after the surging River Indus smashed through levees in two places, but many refused to leave the danger zone while others took shelter in an ancient graveyard for Muslim saints.
The Taliban threat is likely to complicate the massive relief effort, while more than 8 (m) million people are in need of emergency assistance across the country.
The United Nations, the Pakistani army and a host of other local and international relief groups have been rushing aid workers, medicine, food and water to the affected regions, but are unable to reach many people.
The Pakistani Taliban on Thursday hinted they might attack the foreign aid workers. The militant network has a history of attacking aid groups, including agencies under the UN umbrella.
Militant spokesman Azam Tariq said the US and other countries were not really focused on providing aid to flood victims but had other motives he did not specify.
Pakistan's information minister promised to protect those who are helping in flood relief efforts. 
"The aid workers, health workers who have come here, federal agencies and the provincial agencies, like police and others, as well, we will provide them proper security," Qamar Zaman Kaira told reporters. 
He said the Taliban are trying to use the crisis to their advantage. 
"The Taliban are basically threatening the whole nation, the whole world," he said. 
"If this mess goes on, then this is in their benefit, this is in the benefit of all those who are against the interests and against the peace of Pakistan and the region and the world." 
However, he added that the Taliban's "capacity and capability" had been weakened. 
The United States - which has launched scores of missile attacks against militant targets in the far northwest over the last 2 1/2 years - hopes to improve its highly unpopular image in Pakistan through its aid efforts. It has deployed 19 civilian and army helicopters to ferry aid and victims.
"Our brothers and sisters who live there face this difficult situation," he said. 


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/b25c96209eedd444ef7bcd34b8fe3b16 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Minority community take refuge from floods in Hindu temple
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Close of toddler with her mother, AUDIO: Hindu religious songs 
2. Wide of a religious celebration in Hindu temple by flood victims 
3. Mid of Goddess  
4. Various of drums being played
5. Women singing
6. SOUNDBITE (Sindhi) Remetha Kumari, Hindu flood victim:
"We were separated from our relatives and came here (referring to the temple), we are celebrating our religious festival here which we celebrated a lot more in our own homes. We are worried for relatives who live there, half of my family is here and half there, two of my sons have been washed away in flood and one died before in an accident."
7. Various of girl worshiping
8. Women clapping and singing
9. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Mahesh Kumar, Head of Hindu temple:
"Today we are celebrating Janmashtami festival, on the Sri Krishna birth anniversary, we are celebrating this religious festival with flood affected  and singing and beating drums to celebrate with them."
10. Sweets being distributed among the worshippers
STORYLINE
Hindu minorities, who escaped the floods across Pakistan and have been taking shelter at a centuries-old Hindu temple, celebrated a religious festival inside the temple on Friday, marking the birth of Hindu God Sri Krishna.
Two hundred Hindus have been taking shelter in Kalka Devi Temple, in Rohri area near Sukkur.
Flood affected people in Sukkur area have been using temples, shrines and mosques as shelter after flood washed away their villages and houses.
Rescue work is still in progress in the area to evacuate the people from the flood waters.
Remetha Kumari, a Hindu flood victim recalled the two-day Janmashtami festival before the flooding.
"We were separated from our relatives and came here (referring to the temple), we are celebrating our religious festival here which we celebrated a lot more in our own homes.....Half of my family is here and half there, two of my sons have been washed away in flood and one died before in an accident." she said.
Pakistan's population is nearly all Muslim.
Many people displaced by the floods in Pakistan were struggling to find shelter, as the United Nations warned it will cost 46 (b) billions of US dollars for Pakistan to recover from the devastation.
More than 1,600 people have been killed and more than 20 (m) millions more left begging for help following the worst floods in the country's history.
The floods have moved down from the mountainous northwest, submerging or affecting almost one-fifth of the country at their peak. 
Waters have begun to recede in the north and in the eastern province of Punjab, but they have been submerging towns in southern Sindh province close to the Indus River over the last 10 days.
The scale of the disaster has raised concerns about the stability of nuclear-armed Pakistan, which is already reeling from al-Qaida and Taliban violence and massive economic woes.
Foreign countries have pledged hundreds of (m) millions of dollars to help Pakistan respond to the floods. 
Even the country's archenemy, India, has offered assistance and has announced that it was increasing its aid from five (m) million to 25 (m) million US dollars.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/06b64b608eb782739b1e8c337c1b49b4 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: WRAP Angelie Jolie news conference on flood victims, meets PM
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of US actress and goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, Angelina Jolie, entering meeting room and shaking hands with Pakistan Minister of State for Foreign Affair Nawabzada Malik Amad Khan 
2. Close of Jolie 
3. Mid of Jolie shaking hands with Government officials 
4. Cutaway of photographer
5. Wide of Pakistan Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gillani entering room and shaking hands with Jolie
6. Close of Jolie
7. Close of Yousaf Raza Gillani
8. Various of meeting.
9. Various of Jolie arriving for news conference
10. Wide of Jolie sitting down for news conference 
11. Various of Jolie just before news conference begins
12. Various of Jolie at news conference
13. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Something happens then you have to assess for an appeal, then you make an appeal, then you wait for the money to come in for the appeal, then you try to.. and all the time, people are waiting to just have basic survival, so we have to find a way to get money and more tools put in place, before disasters hit. And so this is a bigger question of how the international community and the UN function when it comes to this and what we need to do."
14. Cutaway of Jolie's hand 
15. Close-up of Jolie's face 
16. Wide of news conference
17. SOUNDBITE (English) Angelina Jolie, US actress:
"Of course not, of course not. I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book."
18. Mid of news conference 
19. Pan of Jolie leaving after news conference
STORYLINE
Angelina Jolie on Wednesday condemned a Florida church's threat to burn copies of the Quran to mark the ninth anniversary of the September 11 attacks.
The 35-year-old actress spoke out against the proposed burning during a trip to Pakistan to raise awareness about the floods that have devastated the largely Muslim country over the last six weeks. 
She visited in her capacity as a goodwill ambassador for the United Nations's refugee agency, meeting with Pakistan's Prime Minister, Yousaf Raza Gillani and other government officials on Wednesday afternoon.
Jolie's criticism echoed that of top US officials, who have described the church's plan as a disgraceful act and have even warned that it could endanger US troops in Afghanistan and Americans worldwide.
"I have hardly the words that somebody would do that to somebody's religious book," Jolie told reporters in Islamabad after visiting refugees camps in northwestern Pakistan - one of the areas of the country hit hardest by the floods.
The Christian minister organising the Quran burning, Pastor Terry Jones, has said he plans to go ahead in spite of concerns. 
He is part of the Dove World Outreach Centre, a tiny, evangelical Christian church in Gainesville, Florida, with an anti-Islam philosophy.
The issue has not received much attention in Pakistan, where officials and residents have been trying to cope with the devastation caused by floods that first hit the country at the end of July following extremely heavy monsoon rains.
The floods began in the northwest at the end of July after extremely heavy monsoon rains and slowly surged south along the Indus River, swallowing up hundreds of villages and towns and killing more than 1,700 people. 
Another 17 (m) million have been affected by the floods, and many will need emergency assistance to survive.
Jolie, who wore a long dress and covered her hair with a black scarf in keeping with local Muslim custom, expressed her shock at the height the floodwaters had reached.
"We have to find a way to get money and more tools put in place, before disasters hit. And so this is a bigger question of how the international community and the UN function when it comes to this and what we need to do," she said.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/6299a8a5b94703cbcc359e7188034f93

items.title: Profile of woman who lost husband and children in floods
items.description:
1. Low angle shot of flood victim Hayatan Bi Bi walking towards her tent with her mother
2. Hayatan Bi Bi entering tent
3. Wide interior of tent showing Hayatan sitting with her family
4. Mid of Hayatan's husband and mother inside tent
5 Close up of Hayatan's son
6. Wide of Hayatan with her family inside tent
7. Hayatan with her baby girl
8. Close up of Hayatan's baby girl sleeping 
9. SOUNDBITE: (Sindhi) Hayatan Bi Bi, lost her two sons and father in flooding:
"When flood water came to our village every one one was running, my father took my two sons and ran. I followed my father with my other kids, I saw a vehicle and boarded it with my kids but my father and two sons had been taken away by flood water. I reached this camp with my other family member's and now I live in this camp."
9. Close up of Hayatan 
10. Low angle of Hayatan and her kids
11. Wide of tent village
12. Mid of tent village, children sitting on cart
13. Mid of child with his mother in tent village
14. Close up of child
15. Wide of tent village
16. Young girl hanging cloths
17. Various of children swimming in flood water
18. Various top shots of tent village
STORYLINE:
Driven from their homes by Pakistan's devastating floods, hundreds of thousands of people in Sindh province have been housed in tented camps.
At one camp in Sukkur Sindh on Wednesday morning Hayatan Bi Bi spoke of her loss, her two sons and father dragged away by raging flood waters.
"When flood water came to our village every one one was running, my father took my two sons and ran," she recounted, sitting with her mother, husband and other children at the makeshift camp.
"I followed my father with my other kids, I saw a vehicle and boarded it with my kids but my father and two sons had been taken away by flood water."
Hayatan said she lost all her possessions and she and her family are now reliant on government aid. 
Floods have isolated about 800,000 people in Pakistan who are now only reachable by air and aid workers need at
least 40 more helicopters to ferry lifesaving aid to the increasingly desperate people, the United Nations said.
The appeal on Tuesday was an indication of the massive problems facing the relief effort in Pakistan more than three weeks after the floods hit the country, affecting more than 17 million (m) people and raising concerns about possible social unrest and political instability.
The floods began with hammering monsoon rains in the northwest and have swept southwards.
The aid group World Vision said it could be three months until some families are able to return to their homes.
Local charities, the Pakistani army and international agencies are providing food, water, medicine and shelter to the displaced, but millions (m) have received little or no help.
The UN High Commissioner for Refugees estimates that about 700,000 Pakistanis have been forced into makeshift settlements just in the southern province of Sindh.
Earlier, Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani said hundreds of health facilities had been damaged and tens of thousands of medical workers displaced and the country's chief meteorologist warned that it would be two weeks until the Indus River, the focus of the flooding still sweeping through the country, returns to normal levels.
The death toll in the floods had been around 1,500 people but they rank as one of Pakistan's worst ever disasters
because of their scale and the massive economic damage, especially to the country's vital agricultural sector.

items.title: Fmr Pakistan cricket capt comments on scandal, floods
items.description:
1. Mid of Imran Khan, former Pakistan cricket team captain talking to displaced people at distribution centre 
2. SOUNDBITE: (English) Imran Khan, former captain of Pakistan cricket team:
"I can't comment on what Yasir has said because he is denying it. I, you know, if he was recorded, it was obviously not on the record, and whatever has come on the record he is denying it. So until, you know we know the exact truth, I can't comment on what Yasir has said."
3. Mid of displaced at distribution centre 
4. SOUNDBITE: (English) Imran Khan, former captain of Pakistan cricket team:
"I think everyone now acknowledges that Pakistan (unclear word) when first the match fixing allegations appeared. A thorough investigation should have been done and then those found guilty should have been given exemplary punishment. Had that happened at the time, and I am talking about '93 - that is when they first appeared, because I was captain for ten years - there were no match fixing allegations in those ten years. I leave in '92, '93 was the first time they appeared, and the first investigation took place. I wish that they had followed it right through and steps should have been taken then, we would not be facing this humiliation right now."
5. Wide of distribution centre 
6. SOUNDBITE: (English) Imran Khan, former captain of Pakistan cricket team:
"At the moment the only thing we know is that there are three players implicated in spot, spot betting. Until the investigation is completed, we won't know, but if these allegations are proved to be correct, that the players were involved in spot fixing, then it opens a huge Pandora's box. What else could have happened? What other players could have been involved? So we don't know really, at the moment. We hope that this is not true, but if these allegations prove to be true, then there are a lot of repercussions very damaging for Pakistan cricket."
7. Khan sitting with group of men
8. Mid of Khan at distribution centre
9. SOUNDBITE: (English) Imran Khan, former captain of Pakistan cricket team:
"It is a difficult, sad time for Pakistan cricket because it's very demoralising, you know, when you see the plight of people here and the floods, then before that the war on terror that has claimed over 30 thousand casualties in Pakistan, destroyed our economy, millions internally displaced people because of the war on terror."
+++FINISHES ON SOUNDBITE+++
STORYLINE
During a visit to a food distribution centre in the flood stricken area of Khan Ghar in South Punjab on Sunday, former Pakistan cricket captain Imran Khan said that if betting scam allegations are proved to be true, it would be "very damaging for Pakistan cricket." 
Khan told reporters that it was a difficult and sad time for Pakistan cricket. 
The former cricketer lamented that a thorough investigation was not done when match fixing allegations first appeared in 1993. "I wish that they had followed it right through and steps should have been taken then, we would not be facing this humiliation right now."
Pakistan's spot-fixing crisis deepened on Sunday after an undercover reporter for a British newspaper allegedly caught opening batsman Yasir Hameed claiming some of his team-mates had been fixing "almost every cricket match."
Hameed's interview, published in the News of the World, followed last Sunday's allegations that Pakistani cricketers - Salman Butt, Mohammad Asif and Mohammad Aamir - accepted offers from an apparent bookmaker to deliberately bowl no-balls during the fourth test against England at Lords.
Asif, Amir and Butt were charged and suspended by the International Cricket Council on Thursday and questioned by police on Friday over allegations they were involved in manipulating matches, first raised in the News of the World.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Villagers evacuated from flood area by hovercraft
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of people evacuating the area, carrying belongings due to flood warning  
2. Various of people walking down road carrying belongings
3. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Riaz Ali, Villager: 
"Due to flood water we are evacuating our village. The government is not supporting us, we are not receiving any aid. We don't have food or drinking water, as you saw we are evacuating our village with empty hands and are looking for a safe place."
4. Wide of people at side of road next to water filling bags with sand, pan across flooded area
5. Various of villagers filling bags with sand 
6. Various of men putting wood and sand bags at the edge of water to try to stop it spreading
7. Various tracking shots from boat showing houses surrounded by flood water
8. Women and children climbing into hovercraft after being rescued 
9. Wide of rescued families sitting in boat 
10. Tracking shot of houses submerged in flood water
11. Various of rescued people climbing out of hovercraft, being helped by soldiers 
STORYLINE
More Pakistanis were forced to move to higher ground on Monday as floodwaters from a freshly swollen Indus River submerged dozens more towns and villages in the south.
Across Pakistan flood victims were continuing to struggle without adequate shelter, food or clean water as many fled flooded areas.
Six-hundred-thousand people were already in relief camps set up across Pakistan during the flooding over the past month.
In Thatta, in Sindh province, local people were fleeing their homes on Monday after authorities issued more flood warnings. 
One man said they were leaving with nothing and had not received any government help.
Elsewhere in the area, villagers laid sandbags to try to prevent floodwaters from submerging a road. 
The Pakistani army used hovercraft to rescue people stranded by the rising water. Many homes in the area were already submerged. 
Authorities piled stones and sandbags to strengthen embankments protecting the city of Shadad Kot in Sindh from rising waters as the floods moved slowly south after leaving thousands of square kilometres (miles) of destruction in their wake.
On the eastern side of the city, the embankment was under pressure from nine-foot high waters, said Yaseen Shar, the top administrative official there.
Most of the city's 350-thousand people have moved to relief camps or to towns and cities away from the danger.
Local charities, the Pakistani army and international agencies are providing food, water, medicine and shelter to the displaced, but (m) millions have received little or help. 
Aid officials warn that waterborne diseases like cholera now posed a real threat.
The disaster has left around six (m) million people homeless from the mountainous north to the plains in the south, where the floods are expected to drain into the Arabian Ocean in the coming days and weeks.
The shaky government has come under criticism for its response, and will require (b) billions of dollars in foreign aid to rebuild.

items.title: Family seek refuge in school after their house is destroyed
items.description:
1. Wide exterior of school where flood victims are taking shelter 
2. Mid of school entrance 
3. Wide of family sitting inside classroom 
4. Mid of mother with her children 
5. Close of an infant sleeping
6. Various of child eating 
7. Close up of food
8. SOUNDBITE: (Sindhi) Waali Khan, flood victim:
"My house, hut, all swept away in floodwater. I lost everything. I did not get any relief items. I have no place to live,  no clothes, only the clothes I stand up in. Where will we go after this school shelter? The government should make some arrangement for us to live."
9. Mid of family in school room
10. Various of doctor checking flood victim
11. Close of medicines
12. Wide of school corridor
STORYLINE:
As Pakistan authorities on Monday warned of more flooding to come in the week ahead, those displaced by the country's worst floods in recorded history struggle to find clean water, food and shelter.
One family in Sindh province have found refuge in a local school, for now.
Waali Khan said her house and all the family's possessions had been washed away in the flood water which ravaged her town of Sukkur in Sindh province.
She said she had received no form of assistance from authorities.
"Where will we go after this school shelter? The government should make some arrangement for us to live," Khan said.
Pakistan's floods began more than two weeks ago in the mountainous northwest and have spread throughout the country. 
Some 20 (m) million people and 160,000 square kilometres (61,776 miles) of land - about 1/5 of the country - have been affected.
A massive international relief effort is already under way, but aid has not yet reached all the victims.
UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon visited Sindh province on Sunday and said he had never seen a disaster on such a scale.
He appealed for an initial 460 (m) million dollars to provide relief, of which around 60 per cent has been given.
(B) Billions more will be needed for reconstruction once the flood waters recede.
Sindh province's irrigation minister said on Monday a dam in Sukkur, a hard hit area in the province, was facing a major test of its strength as flood waters coursed down the River Indus into Pakistan's highly populated agricultural heartland.

items.title: Arrival of Japanese plane carrying aid for flood survivors
items.description:
SHOTLIST
++PART MUTE AS MUTE++
1. Wide of Japanese aid plane arriving at Multan International Airport in Punjab province
2. Close up of plane logo
3. Wide of Japanese soldiers walking towards plane
4. Close up of pilot seen through cockpit window
5. Various of Japanese soldiers unloading aid from plane
6. SOUNDBITE: (Japanese) Colonel Shizaki, Japanese Army:
++NO TRANSLATION AVAILABLE++
7. Various of soldiers unloading plane
8. SOUNDBITE:  (Japanese) Colonel Shizaki, Japanese Army:
++NO TRANSLATION AVAILABLE++
9. Various of Japanese soldiers loading aid onto trucks
STORYLINE:
A Japanese plane loaded with aid for Pakistan's flood victims arrived at Multan International Airport in Punjab province on Wednesday.
Soldiers under the command of Colonel Shizaki unloaded boxes and crates of food and other relief items from the plane to be distributed by truck.
The Pakistan government has said about 800 (m) million US dollars in emergency aid has been committed or pledged so far.
But there are concerns internationally about how the money will be spent by the government, which has a reputation for inefficiency and corruption.
The US aid chief said on Tuesday that Pakistan will have to demonstrate it can spend relief funds transparently and well if it wants more help in rebuilding after the devastating floods. 
America has been the most generous contributor to the flood aid, rushing in emergency assistance to support a vital ally in the war against al-Qaida and Taliban. 
But rebuilding homes, roads, livelihoods and vital infrastructure will cost billions of dollars, and there are questions over who will pay.
The floods began almost a month ago with the onset of the monsoon and have ravaged a massive swath of the country, from the mountainous north through to its agricultural heartland. 
More than 8 (m) million people are in need of emergency assistance.

items.title: Field hospital struggles to cope with flood victims
items.description:
SHOTLIST
Government Technical College IDP (Internally Displaced Person) camp
1. Wide exterior of Flood Field Hospital compound, ambulance passing through (AUDIO: siren)
2. Close of sign (Urdu: "Flood Field Hospital, health department Mardan"
3. Wide of interior, doctors treating patients
4. Mid of volunteers giving first aid to a wounded patient
5. Mid of doctor checking a female patient
6. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Gulzar Hussain, camp doctor:
"We are treating patients with diarrhoea everyday and send them back to their tents or home, but we have not identified any case of cholera here yet".
7. Cutaway, doctor writing a prescription
8. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Gulzar Hussain, camp doctor:
"In the camp the necessary things we need are medicine and equipment. If we have updated equipments then we can treat the patients well. An ambulance is also very important as the day before yesterday there was a case of delivery and we didn't have a vehicle here at that time so we used a World Health Organisation vehicle which was here at that time. We sent the patient to Mardan DHQ (District Headquarters) Hospital".
9. Mid of female patient on bed with her new-born twins
10. Close up of twins 
11. Mid of patients in bed
12. Wide pan right of ward
13. Low angle of a woman fanning her ill child
14. Wide pan left of tents
STORYLINE:
Medical staff at a field hospital in Nowshera district, requested more medicine and equipment on Saturday, as they continued to try and treat the sick and injured civilians displaced by the flooding.  
"In the camp the necessary things we need are medicine and equipment. If we have updated equipments then we can treat the patients well," said 
Gulzar Hussain, a doctor struggling to run the field hospital at a government technical college in Nowshera, 27 miles east of Peshawar in the country's Northwest.
"The day before yesterday," he said, "There was a case for delivery (birth) and we didn't have a vehicle here."
However, he said that although they have treated many cases of diarrhoea, so far they had not identified any cases of cholera.
The UN High Commission for Refugees said it provides shelter to over 500 families in the Nowshera District and its emergency facility will eventually hold up to 3,000 people affected by the floods. 
World Health Organisation (WHO) said more than 200 health centres or hospitals across the country had been damaged on destroyed in the floods.
Around 150-thousand people are reported to have joined the mass exodus of the Indus River flood plains on Saturday, as floodwaters continued to rise.
In the southern Sindh province, 600-thousand people have set-up relief camps as a result of flooding over the past month.
The waters have washed away houses, roads and crops and smashed key communication and transport infrastructures.
Officials expect the floodwaters will recede nationwide in the next few days as the last river torrents empty into the Arabian Sea. 
The United Nations Food Programme's Pakistan country director, Wolfgang Herbinger, said on Saturday that the programme needs at least 40 more helicopters to reach the large number of people cut off by the flooding.
The floods have affected about one-fifth of Pakistan's territory, straining its civilian government as it also struggles against al-Qaida and Taliban violence.
At least 8 (m) million people are in need of water, shelter or other emergency assistance, making the disaster larger than Pakistan's last two humanitarian crises, the exodus from Swat last year amid an army offensive against the Taliban and the 2005 Kashmir earthquake.
The country's textile industry is also expected to suffer because of damage to cotton crops.
Already, the prices of vegetables, meat and dairy products have risen sharply across the country.

items.title: Helicopters drop aid to those hit by floods in southern Punjab
items.description:
Jampur, southern Punjab
1. Various aerials showing flooded areas
2. Various of Pakistani soldiers unloading aid supplies from truck, loading helicopter
3. Various of flood victims at distribution centre, police pushing them back
4. SOUNDBITE (English) Captain Usman (full name not given), Pakistan Army:
"We have been deployed over here for the last two weeks, till now we have evacuated almost 2200 people from Tehsil Jampur. Now, basically, the rescue operation is over by now but right now we are majorly focusing on relief operations."
5. Various of food items being dropped from helicopter
6. Various aerials of flood victims
STORYLINE
Pakistani military officials in the Japmur area of Punjab on Tuesday said rescue operations were increasingly turning towards the delivery of relief supplies in the aftermath of devastating flooding.
"We have been deployed over here for the last two weeks, till now we have evacuated almost 2,200 people from Tehsil Jampur," Captain Usman told reporters.
"The rescue operation is over by now but right now we are focusing on relief operations," he said.
The most destructive floods in Pakistan's recorded history have affected an estimated 62-thousand square miles (160-thousand square kilometres) of land - about a fifth of the already poor country. 
Around 20 (m) million people have had their lives disrupted, and 1,500 have been killed.
The scale of the disaster has overwhelmed authorities and led to fears of social unrest, especially given the weak and unpopular government. 
Hundreds of thousands are living in makeshift camps or by the side of the road, soaking up monsoon rains and surviving on handouts. 
Many have brought their valuable livestock with them.
The disruption in food supplies is causing price increases across the country.

items.title: Waterborne diseases such as cholera spreading after floods
items.description:
NB STORY IS NOT ON TAPE
1. Guarded entrance to Dera Ismail Khan district hospital 
2. Close of D I Khan hospital sign 
3. Wide exterior of people entering hospital
4. People entering children's ward where flood-affected children admitted
5. Wide of children's ward
6. Various of doctor checking flood-affected children
7. SOUNDBITE: (Saraiki) Nafeesa Bi Bi, mother of child patient:
"Floods totally destroyed our village and houses, our children have become sick. The government must help us out.''
8. Mother with her sick child in hospital bed
9. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Fazal Rehman, doctor at DI Khan hospital:
''The recent flood was very devastating. Most of the children coming to us have diarrhoea and vomiting. We have treated 100 to 200 patients. Most of them have been discharged, but we are giving treatment to 30 to 50 patients on a daily basis.''
10. Various of mothers with sick children in ward
11. Wide of children's ward
STORYLINE:
As Pakistan's authorities on Monday warned of more flooding to come in the week ahead, flood victims, particularly children, are beginning to contract water-borne diseases.
Hundreds of people suffering from diarrhoea and vomiting reported to to the Dera Ismail Khan government hospital in Peshawar on Monday.
Medical staff at the hospital in north west Pakistan said they have limited beds to admit patients, and the priority was sick children.
"We have treated 100 to 200 patients. Most of them have been discharged, but we are giving treatment to 30 to 50 patients on a daily basis,'' said Doctor Fazal Rehman.
Cholera, which can spread rapidly after floods and other disasters, poses a dangerous threat.
The disease has been detected in the northwest, but there have been only a few reported cases so far.
Pakistan's worst floods in recorded history began more than two weeks ago in the mountainous northwest and have spread throughout the country. 
Some 20 (m) million people and 160,000 square kilometres (61,776 miles) of land - about one fifth of the country - have been affected.
The scale of the disaster has raised concerns it could destabilise the country, which is pivotal to US hopes of defeating al-Qaida and the Taliban, has a weak and unpopular government, and an anaemic economy propped up by international assistance.
The United Nations has appealed for an initial 460 (m) million US dollars to provide relief, of which around 60 percent has been given.
Once the floods recede, (b) billions more will be needed for reconstruction and getting people back to work in the already-poor nation of 170 (m) million people. 
While local charities and international agencies have helped hundreds of thousands of people with food, water, shelter and medical treatment, the scale of the disaster has meant that many millions have received little or no assistance. 
The UN has voiced fears that disease in overcrowded and unsanitary relief camps may yet cause more deaths.

items.title: Flooding in Punjab province; people leaving, queueing for food
items.description:
AUGUST 13 2010
1. Wide of people walking in floodwater in road
2. Close-up of floodwater flowing in road
3. Various of people moving from the area, carrying their cattle and belongings through floodwater
4.SOUNDBTIE: (Saraiki) Allah Wasai, flood victim
"My house was swept away in flood water, I have no shelter, no clothes and nothing to eat. I am living in misery. I lost everything, I'm now in God's mercy."
5. Wide of army vehicles arriving in flood water to take people to safety
6. Various of flood victims getting into army vehicle
7. Wide of people moving from the area on trucks and trolleys
8. SOUNDBTIE: (Saraiki) Mohammad Umar, flood victim
"All our houses were swept away due to floodwater. All my grain, wheat, cattle and all household items were swept away. No one came to help us, not even from the government side. Nothing to eat, we are fed-up."
9. Various of women standing in queue to receive food
10. Various of people receiving food
11. Wide of people in queue for food
12. Child eating
13. Wide of queue
STORYLINE:
A case of the deadly, waterborne disease cholera has been confirmed in Pakistan's flood-ravaged northwest, and aid workers expect it is not isolated, the UN said on Saturday. 
The chilling discovery underscores the latest threat to the (m) millions whose lives have been disrupted by the crisis and came as new flood surges hit the south.
Pakistan toned down its usually festive Independence Day celebrations on Saturday amid a flooding disaster that has displaced (m) millions of its citizens, damaged its economy and undermined its political stability as Islamist extremist violence continues.
Officials cancelled the colourful, fireworks-heavy ceremony normally held at midnight on August 14, the anniversary of Pakistan's creation and independence from Britain in 1947. 
But Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani participated in a flag-raising in the morning, and TV channels broadcast stories about the South Asian country's early years.
Government leaders were expected to spend much of the day visiting flood victims amid warnings that more surges may be on the way, threatening cities and towns along main rivers. 
The floods have disrupted the lives of 14 (m) million people - 8 percent of the population. 
Triggered by unusually heavy monsoon rains, the floods have torn through the country from its mountainous northwest, where the fight against al-Qaida and the Taliban is taking place, and spread down the country's major rivers to the heavily populated Punjab and Sindh provinces.
They destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes and an estimated 1.7 (m) million acres (nearly 700-thousand hectares) of farmland.
In Muzaffargarh, a major city of about 250-thousand people in Punjab province, people were evacuating the flood waters on foot, by truck and on trolleys on Friday, carrying whatever belongings they could save. 
"My house was swept away in flood water, I have no shelter,no clothes and nothing to eat. I am living in misery," said one flood victim. 
In southern Pakistan, the river Indus is now more than 15 miles (25 kilometres) wide at some points - 25 times wider than during normal monsoon seasons.
Many flood victims are living in muddy camps or overcrowded government buildings, while thousands more are sleeping in the open next to their cows, goats and whatever possessions they managed to drag with them. 
The UN has appealed for 460 (m) million US dollars to help Pakistan get immediate relief, but officials have said the country will need (b) billions to rebuild after the waters recede.
Pakistan was already struggling to battle a violent Islamist militant movement on its soil, and its offensives were considered important to the US goals in the war in neighbouring Afghanistan.

items.title: Pakistan tones down Independence Day celebrations amid flooding disaster
items.description:
SHOTLIST
++QUALITY AS INCOMING++  
1. Governor of Sindh Province Ishrat Ul Ibad Khan (left) and Chief Minister of Sindh Qaim Ali Shah (right) raising Pakistani flag at independence day ceremony at Quaid-e-Azam mausoleum
2. Close-up of flag being raised
3. Various of honour guards and officials carrying wreaths in procession 
4. Wide of wreaths being laid on grave of founder of Pakistan Mohammad Ali Jinnah (known popularly as Quaid-e-Azam)
5. Close-up of buglers playing
6. Mid of Honour Guard in ceremony 
7. Ishrat Ul Ibad Khan and Qaim Ali Shah and other officials praying
8. Wide pan of Ishrat Ul Ibad Khan walking to rostrum
9. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Ishrat Ul Ibad Khan, Governor of Sindh Province:
"At this time, our country is facing problems and we have to contend with this flooding disaster and other problems with unity, faith and discipline. We are with the flood-affected people and now we need the same unity, the same emotions as we had when we got freedom and created our country." 
10. Wide of journalists
STORYLINE:
Pakistan toned down its Independence Day celebrations on Saturday amid a flooding disaster that has displaced (m) millions of its citizens.
Officials cancelled the colourful, fireworks ceremony normally held at midnight on August 14, the anniversary of Pakistan's creation and independence from Britain in 1947. 
But smaller events still went ahead, including a wreath-laying ceremony at the Quaid-e-Azam mausoleum in Karachi, where Pakistan's founder Mohammad Ali Jinnah is buried.
Sindh Province Governor Ishrat Ul Ibad Khan and Chief Minister Qaim Ali Shah laid wreaths on the grave, accompanied by a guard of honour. 
Sindh Province has been hit hard by the flooding. Fresh flood water swelled the River Indus on Saturday, threatening more cities, towns and villages in the province.
In a televised address to the nation Prime Minister Yousuf Raza Gilani said 20 (m) million were now homeless. 
He did not elaborate, and it was unclear how many of those people were briefly forced to leave their homes and how many had lost their houses altogether.
Gilani also participated in a flag-raising ceremony on Saturday morning. 
The floods have disrupted the lives of at least 14 (m) million people - 8 percent of the population. 
Triggered by unusually heavy monsoon rains, the floods have swept south through the country.
In southern Pakistan, the River Indus is now more than 15 miles (25 kilometres) wide at some points - 25 times wider than during normal monsoon seasons.
The UN said on Saturday that a case of cholera has been confirmed in Pakistan's northwest and aid workers expect it is not isolated.

items.title: Latest on floods in Punjab, mother with sick child
items.description:
1. Various of people attempting to cross floodwater holding rope 
2. Wide of damaged road under flowing floodwater 
3. Mid of people carrying belongings walking through floodwater 
4. Wide of Ghulam Hafeeza walking through floodwater with her three children, one of them sick
5. SOUNDBITE: (Saraiki Native Language) Ghulam Hafeeza, flood victim:
"My son has been suffering from vomiting and diarrhoea since yesterday. Last night I took him to the hospital and he was injected with (IV) drips all night. I spent the whole night in hospital. Today in the morning the doctor advised me to take him to Muzaffarghar hospital. How I can go? Nobody is with me, floodwater is everywhere. I don't have money. My house and everything was swept away. I have two sons and one daughter. I am carrying my children and finding my way."
6. Close-up of Hafeeza holding sick child, her daughter next to her
7. Over the shoulder shot Hafeeza walking holding sick child
8. Various of people walking through floodwater
9. Various of school inundated in floodwater 
10. Close-up of flood victims standing and laying beside rail track 
STORYLINE
More rain soaked flood-ravaged Pakistan on Saturday and even heavier downpours were forecast for coming days, deepening a crisis which Pakistani officials estimate as affected as many as 13 million (m) people throughout the South Asian nation.
About 1,500 people have died, most of them in the northwest, the hardest-hit region. 
Mass evacuations are under way in the southern province of Sindh after the Indus River rose there.
The intense flooding that began about two weeks ago has washed away roads, bridges and many communications lines, hampering rescue efforts. 
Incessant monsoon rains have grounded many helicopters trying to rescue people and ferry aid, including six choppers manned by US troops on loan from Afghanistan.
Floodwaters receded somewhat on Friday in the northwest, but downpours in the evening and early Saturday again swelled rivers and streams. 
Pakistani meteorologists said heavy rains in Afghanistan were expected to make things even worse over the next 36 hours as the bloated Kabul River surged into Pakistan's northwest.
That will likely mean more woes for Punjab and Sindh provinces as well, as new river torrents flow east and south.
In the northwest and Punjab, floods have displaced 12 million (m) people, said an official with the National Disaster Management Authority. 
In the Punjab city of Kot Addu, flood victim Ghulam Hafeeza walked through floodwaters with her three children, one of them sick, trying to make it to a hospital almost 90 kilometres (60 miles) from where she was. 
"My son has been suffering from vomiting and diarrhoea since yesterday. Last night I took him to the hospital and he was injected with (IV) drips all night. I spent the whole night in hospital," she explained through tears. 
The hospital she took her son to, the Government Civil Hospital of Kot Addu, has also been badly affected by the floods so a doctor advised her to travel the long distance to the Muzaffarghar hospital to get care for her sick child.
"How I can go? Nobody is with me, floodwater is everywhere. I don't have money. My house and everything was swept away. I have two sons and one daughter. I am carrying my children and finding my way," a desperate Hafeeza said as she continued her journey. 
Nearby, some attempted to cross raging floodwaters using ropes while others carried their belongings through knee deep water. 
In Sindh province, about 1 million (m) people have been evacuated or are being helped out of their homes, said the provincial irrigation minister.
Authorities have given varying tolls for the number of people among Pakistan's 175 million (m) impacted by the floods.

items.title: Latest on floods as Pakistan begins moving people away, PM sbite
items.description:
SHOTLIST
Kot Addu, Punjab province
1. Various aerial shots of floods, fields submerged in water
2. Various shots of flood victims standing and waiting for aid to arrive
3. Pan of collapsed road
4. SOUNDBITE (English) Ikhlaq Tarar, Relief Commissioner in Punjab province:
"So far eight districts of the province of Punjab have been affected by these exceptionally high floods. And 12-hundred and 61 villages have been affected, around 1.5 million (of the) population has been rendered homeless. So far, flood related deaths in Punjab province are around 15."
District of Jhelum, Punjab province
5. Aerial shots of neighbourhoods submerged in flood water
6. Wide aerial shot of dam on River Jhelum
7. Ground shot of dam
8. Close of rapid water
9. Various aerial shots of flood
Islabamad
10. Wide of convocation ceremony
11. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Yusuf Raza Gilani, Pakistani Prime Minister:
"The big issue was evacuating these people.  We are evacuating them and, afterwards, providing them with relief. To provide them with tents, food, protection, shelter and medicines."
12. Cutaway of Gilani attending ceremony
13. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Yusuf Raza Gilani, Pakistani Prime Minister:
"Now we are doing a damage assessment by credible means, through the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. Afterwards, when all the assessment is completed, certainly we will compensate these people who were martyred (killed) and were swept away."
14. Wide of ceremony
STORYLINE
The Pakistani army used boats and helicopters to move stranded villagers in the country's eastern Punjab province to higher ground as many parts of the region remained submerged in flood water.
An aerial view from a military helicopter showed a vast area around the districts of Kot Addu and Jhelum almost entirely underwater, with only rooftops sticking out from beneath the surface.
The province's relief commissioner said on Thursday that 1,261 villages had been affected by the floods, with around 1.5 (m) million people rendered homeless.
"So far, flood related deaths in Punjab province are around 15," Ikhlaq Tarar said.
The region's army commander said many people had ignored flood warnings and only realised the danger of the situation when water had already entered their cities, towns and villages.
In the country's south, meanwhile, authorities began evacuating half-a-million people as the worst monsoon rains in decades threatened new destruction.
In the northwest, the US army have joined international aid agencies, airlifting hundreds of stranded people and distributing emergency food.
The floods have already killed an estimated 1,500 people over the past week, most in the northwest.
The Pakistani government response to the floods has been criticized, especially because President Asif Ali Zardari left for a visit to Europe soon after the crisis began.
As fresh rains fell on Thursday, bloated rivers gushed toward southern Sindh province, where hundreds of thousands of the most impoverished Pakistanis live along the water because of fertile soil.
Many flood victims have also complained that aid is not reaching them fast enough or at all.
Pakistani Prime Minister, Yusuf Raza Gilani, said on Thursday that evacuations had been the biggest issue for the government.
"The big issue was evacuating these people.  We are evacuating them and, afterwards, providing them with relief. To provide them with tents, food, protection, shelter and medicines," he said, speaking in Islamabad.
Gilani added that the government is starting to assess the damage with the help of the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank.
"When all the assessment is completed, certainly we will compensate these people who were martyred (killed) and were swept away."

items.title: Chinese aid arrives for flood victims as disaster continues
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of Chinese plane carrying aid for Pakistan flood victims taxiing at Chaklala Air Base in Rawalpindi
2. Close of Chinese flag on plane tail wing
3. Various of aid items being unloaded from Chinese plane
4. Various of tents sent from China being unloaded
5. Close up label on tent: China Aid with Chinese flag
5. Tents being unloaded
6. SOUNDBITE (English) Liu Jian, Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan:
"To show our solidarity and our good sentiments, Chinese government decided to provide the Pakistani government with humanitarian emergency goods worth 10 million Renminbi, which include water filtration equipment, electronic generators, tents and medicines."
7. Second Chinese plane carrying aid taxiing on tarmac after arrival
8. Relief items being unloaded
9. Wide of crates of Chinese aid 
10. Tents in back of luggage truck being taken away from plane
STORYLINE
China delivered humanitarian aid worth approximately 1.48 (m) million US dollars to Pakistan on Wednesday to help the victims of Pakistan's flooding.
The country's aid supplies, which included water filtration equipment, electronic generators, tents and medicines, arrived on Wednesday at the Chaklala Air Base in Rawalpindi.
Chinese Ambassador to Pakistan, Liu Jian, said that his country had sent the aid to show its "solidarity" with flood victims.
"Chinese government decided to provide the Pakistani government with humanitarian emergency goods worth 10 million Renminbi," he added.
Floodwaters continued ravaging hundreds of villages in Pakistan, destroying homes, soaking crops, and threatening more lives. 
Aid workers warned that bloated rivers would soon surge into the country's south, prompting more evacuations.
This year's monsoon season has prompted the worst flooding in Pakistan in living memory and already killed more than 1,500 people. 
The UN scrambled to provide food and other assistance to some 3.2 (m) million affected people in a nation already struggling with an Islamist militancy and a poor economy.
The loss of farm produce is one reason the UN has warned of serious food shortages, and the World Food Program has estimated that 1.8 (m) million people will need to be fed over the next month.
Rescue workers have struggled to deliver aid because of washed-out bridges and roads and downed communication lines.
Several foreign countries have stepped in to help, including the United States, which announced on Tuesday that it was sending six large military helicopters from Afghanistan to help with the relief effort.
But many flood victims have complained that aid is not reaching them fast enough or at all.

items.title: AP focus on one family's efforts to cope with flood disaster
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Various of BiBi Shehnaz, who lost her child while fleeing floods, holding her second child
2. Wide of Shehnaz sitting with others on a cot
3. SOUNDBITE (Pashto) BiBi Shehnaz, Mother who lost her son in floods:
"While we were sleeping I heard a loud voice of a villager warning us to run because the floods were coming. While I was trying to flee, a child of mine was slipped away from my hands and was swept away by the gushing water, I do not know his whereabouts yet."
4. Shehnaz and others taking shelter from rain
5. Woman rushing for shelter to avoid rain
6. Flood victims bringing their cattle inside for shelter from rain
7. Pan from people under shelter to rain outside
8. Various of people walking in rain
9. Various of cattle and people taking shelter from rain
10. Various of flood victims cooking food
11. Close of children
12. SOUNDBITE (Pashto) Abdul Rehman, Local Resident:
"Government hasn't done enough for us, I will appeal to the government at least to help the children."
13. Wide of entrance to college building being used as camp for flood victims
14. Close of college sign reading (English), "College Charsadda"
15. Various of food distribution among flood victims
16. Pan of tents setup for flood victims
STORYLINE
Fresh downpours hit Pakistan's devastated northwest Tuesday, as flood waters submerged dozens of villages along bloated rivers whose torrents have killed at least 1,500 people and put thousand more at risk of disease. 
Of the 3.2 (m) million people affected by flooding, 2.5 (m) million live in the northwest, a UNICEF spokesman told reporters in Geneva.
In the Peshawar district of Charsadda on Tuesday residents were struggling to come to grips with the devastation of the worst flooding in generations.
Many sought cover from the new rains Tuesday as they huddled, many with their livestock at makeshift shelters and relief points.
At one such shelter a woman who had lost her son in the floods described the moment she felt her little one's hand slip away from hers. 
"While we were sleeping I heard a loud voice of a villager warning us to run because the floods were coming. While I was trying to flee, a child of mine was slipped away from my hands and was swept away by the gushing water," BiBi Shehnaz said.
"I do not know his whereabouts yet," she said, recounting a tale that has become all too familiar in the region. 
The fresh rains in the hardest-hit northwest threatened to overwhelm a major dam and unleash a new deluge.
Relief work for some 3.2 million people has been delayed by swamped roads, washed-out bridges and downed communication lines, and survivors have complained about government inaction. 
"Government hasn't done enough for us, I will appeal to the government at least to help the children," said one villager Tuesday. 
The loss of so many crops was one reason the UN's World Food Program estimated that some 1.8 (m) million Pakistanis would need food assistance for at least the next month.
Aside from farmers, many victims have small businesses that have been destroyed and won't have the means to buy food for their families, a WFP
(World Food Programme) spokeswoman said in Geneva.
The northwest is the epicentre of Pakistan's battle against al-Qaida and the Taliban. 
Alongside military and police operations, the government - with the support of the West - has tried to improve its services and living standards there to blunt the appeal of militancy.
The Pakistani army, which has the helicopters, boats and infrastructure needed for relief work, is delivering food, medicine and tents, as are government agencies and several different political parties and welfare organisations.
But many flood victims were unhappy with the response.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Aftermath of floods that have killed more than 900 people
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of houses and dead buffalos under flood water
2. Man pushing dead buffalo with stick in flood water
3. Dead buffalo in water
4. Various of cow standing on roof of house
5. Villager Habib Khan leading buffalo away from flood area
6. SOUNDBITE: (Pashto) Habib Khan, local villager:
"My two oxen, eight buffalos and two cows have died in the floods, just found one alive, I am coming back from a safe place where the water level was low, this buffalo has been kept in the second floor of a house for three days."
7. Wide of timber shop with men standing in flood water
8. Timber shop owner collecting wood from water
9. Planks of wood covered in mud
10. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Shair Dad, timber shop owner:
"I haven't covered my losses in ten years, we are buying this wood on credit, I don't know how I will be able pay it back"
11. Wide of area under flood water
STORYLINE
Rescue workers struggled on Sunday to save more than 27,000 people still trapped by massive flooding in Pakistan's northwest that has killed over 900 people and destroyed thousands of homes, officials said.
The effort has been aided by a slackening of the monsoon rains that have caused the worst flooding in decades in Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa province. 
But as flood waters have started to recede, authorities have begun to understand the full scale of the disaster.
In Nowshera city - where water levels were dropping on Sunday - some people were slowly making their way back to their houses.
Shair Dad, a timber shop owner, said his business has been badly affected by the floods.
"I haven't covered my losses in ten years, we are buying this wood on credit, I don't know how I will be able pay it back," he said on Sunday.
The death toll from the flooding has risen to 903 people, said Mujahid Khan, the head of rescue services for the Edhi Foundation, a private charity.
The worst hit areas have been the districts of Swat and Shangla, where more than 400 people have died, he said.
Authorities have deployed 43 military helicopters and over 100 boats to try to rescue some 27,300 people still trapped by the floods.       
The military has deployed 30,000 army troops who had evacuated 19,000 trapped people by Saturday night, said an army spokesman. 
But the scale of the disaster has strained the resources of a government already grappling with a faltering economy and a brutal war against the Taliban.
The floods have caused an acute shortage of fruits and vegetables in the northwest because many of the hardest hit areas were the key centres of production, officials said.
The threat of disease loomed as well as some evacuees arrived in temporary camps with fever, diarrhea and skin problems.
A variety of nations and aid organisations have begun to mobilise a response to the flood disaster.
The US delivered 380,000 food packages, four rescue boats and two water filtration units to the Provincial Disaster Management Authority, said a spokesman for the Provincial Disaster Management Authority.
The US Embassy in Islamabad has also announced it will provide 12 prefabricated steel bridges to temporarily replace some of the spans damaged by the water.
Floodwaters were receding in the northwest, Pakistani officials said, but fresh rains were expected to lash other parts of the country in the coming days.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/7da343e1357b0bb25d7a3d9571210bcf 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Aid is delivered to victims of floods that killed more than 800
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Pakistan military helicopter flying
2. Soldiers riding in helicopter
3. Aerial zoom out to wide of flood-hit village in Dera Ismail Khan
4. Soldier surveying flood damaged from helicopter
5. Aerial of flood-hit houses in Dera Ismail Khan
6. Soldiers disembarking from helicopter in Parowa village, Dera Ismail Khan
7. Soldiers unloading relief supplies from helicopter
8. Man walks with donkey cart through flood water
9. Various of civil defence force members setting up camp in Dera Ismail Khan
10. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Anwar Ullah Khan, Civil Defence Official:
"We don't have enough facilities from the government side. We have no vehicles for any emergency situations to take any injured to hospital. We are working here with our own funds and also we are purchasing medicine out of own pockets from the bazaar. This time we have some medicine and some medicine will come after some time."
11. Civil defence member walking with box of medicine 
12. Emergency kit at civil defence camp
13. Mid of flood water in Indus river
14. Wide of flood water in Indus river 
STORYLINE 
Flooding in Pakistan has killed more than 800 people in a week, a government official said on Saturday as rescuers struggled to reach marooned victims and some evacuees showed signs of fever, diarrhoea and other waterborne diseases.
The flooding caused by record-breaking rainfalls caused massive destruction in the past week, especially in the northwest province, where officials said it was the worst deluge since 1929. 
The United Nations estimated on Saturday that some 1 (m) million people nationwide were affected by the disaster, though it didn't specify exactly what that meant.
The information minister for the northwest province, Mian Iftikhar Hussain, said reports coming in from various districts across the northwest showed that more than 800 people had died due to the flooding. Many people remain missing.
Floodwaters were receding in the northwest, officials said, but fresh rains were expected to lash other parts of the country in the coming days.
In Dera Ismail Khan, a military helicopter landed with soldiers bearing relief supplies. 
But Anwar Ullah Khan, a civil defence official, complained that they weren't receiving enough aid. 
He said that there weren't any vehicles available to take injured people to hospital, nor have they received any money to help buy medicine. 
A doctor treating evacuees at a small relief camp in Nowshera in the northeast said some had diarrhoea and others had marks appearing on their skin, causing itching. 
Children and the elderly seemed to have the most problems, Mehmood Jaa said.
Rescuers were using army helicopters, heavy trucks and boats to try reaching flood-hit areas, the UN said. It reported that thousands of homes and roads were destroyed, and at least 45 bridges across the northwest were damaged.
The destruction is slowing the rescue effort, said a government official in Khyber-Pakhtoonkhwa, the northwest province.
The head of the Pakistan Meteorological Department, said that no more rain was expected in the next few days for the northwest and that floodwaters there were receding. 
But Punjab province in the east, Sindh province in the south, and Pakistan's side of the disputed Kashmir region all could expect a lashing over the next three or four days, he said.
Flooding has already affected some of those regions, with more than 21 people dying in Kashmir. A plane crash that killed 152 people in Islamabad on Wednesday also occurred during stormy weather.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/5f93b4cb3f3fc17630357976069c8491
