items.title: People displaced by flooding arrive at a camp in Badin district
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Women carrying their belongings, walking through floodwater
2. Wide of flooded area
3. Dog stranded in floodwater
4. Women standing in front of house
5. Wide of flooded area
6. Various of tents for displaced people affected by floods
7. Women cooking in front of tent
8. Close of young boy eating
9. Low angle shot of family in front of tent
10. Close of bread
11. Various of woman getting water from hand pump
12. Various of family sleeping inside tent
13. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Ali Akbar, displaced Pakistani living in camp:
"The water from rainfall entered our houses, we were rescued by boats. Five to six feet of floodwater reached my village. Our cattle died and we lost some human lives. The Al-Khidmat foundation rescued us and brought us here to this camp. We are thankful to them, they give us food twice a day. In the camp we have a medical facility. We are satisfied here."
14. Various of relief workers cooking food for displaced people
STORYLINE
Thousands of Pakistani villagers were flushed from their homes in the southern Sindh province, as authorities and international aid groups struggled to respond to Pakistan''s second major bout of flooding in just over a year.
Residents of Tando Bago, in the worst-hit district of Badin, about 200 kilometres from Karachi, were leaving their flooded houses with only the belongings they could carry with them.
Monsoon rains since early August have killed more than 220 people, damaged or destroyed some 665-thousand homes and displaced more than 1.8 (m) million people in Sindh province, according to the government and the UN, which on Sunday made an emergency appeal for funding.
During the past weeks, flood victims have been camping out on roadsides and dry fields, receiving aid from charities.
Ali Akbar, a displaced Pakistani living in a camp near Tando Bago said he and his family have been brought to a camp by a Pakistani aid group, the Al Khidmat Foundation, where they receive medical help and food.
Sindh saw similar scenes during last year''s floods, which at their peak affected all four of the country''s provinces and triggered a massive international aid response. 
While some districts in the region have been flooded out twice, many of the hardest-hit towns and villagers this year were unaffected in 2010.
The return of the floods is testament to the powerful penetration of the monsoon rains that envelop much of Asia at the end of summer. 
As the rain did last year, the floods are undercutting the legitimacy of the shaky government, which is widely disliked and struggling against Islamist militants, political turmoil and massive economic problems.
In 2010, the floods followed the course of the River Indus and its tributaries from the foothills of the Himalayas to the flatlands of Sindh, where the river empties out into the Arabian Sea.
Many of the countries that helped out then, including the US, have mobilised again this year to assist victims.
The US said it paid for food packages for 23-thousand families and its local partners will soon begin handing out tents, clean water and other supplies.
Japan and China have also pledged relief goods or money, according to the Pakistan government.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/8d3fb6821706218005905e74976d0bc8 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Pakistan information minister visits area affected by floods
items.description:
Sanghar District, Sindh Province - 23 September 2011
1. Various aerials of huge flooded area and swathes of houses underwater
2. Cutaway of photographer on board helicopter
3. Various aerials of huge flooded area
4. Floods seen through window of helicopter
4. Pakistan Information Minister, Firdous Ashiq Awan, speaking to media
5. SOUNDBITE: (English) Firdous Ashiq Awan, Pakistan''s Information Minister:
"We discussed through our appeal, an appeal that has been launched through UN to international community. We have focused on three basic items. First one is shelter. These are the tents, they are demanding the tents, you have assessed yourself that they need immediate shelter. Second is their food security. Those people who are living outside their houses, they are displaced, they need some food to eat and to survive themselves and their families".
6. Close-up of child 
7. Women and children in camp
8. Various of flood water
STORYLINE:
Pakistan''s Information Minister visited the flood-affected area of Sanghar, in Sindh province, on Friday, as authorities and international aid groups continue to struggle to respond to Pakistan''s second major bout of flooding in just over a year.
The heavy monsoon rains in the south have forced hundreds of thousands from their homes and into makeshift tents.
Firdous Ashiq Awan appealed to the international community for tents and food for the displaced.
In Sindh alone, the floods have killed over 220 people, damaged or destroyed some 665,000 homes and displaced more than 1.8 million people, according to the United Nations. 
The Pakistani government was widely criticised last year (2010) for its stuttering response to the worst floods in the country''s history, which affected at least 18 million people and inundated one-fifth of Pakistan - an area the size of the United Kingdom.
The floods have been less severe this year but have still sparked criticism of the government, which is widely disliked and is already struggling against Islamist militants, political turmoil and massive economic problems.
The UN World Food Program said this week that some 3 million (m) people are in need of food assistance in Sindh.

items.title: Monsoon rains kill at least 136 people in the south, floods
items.description:
1. Wide overhead view of Karachi street with rain pouring down
2. Mid overhead view on street with cars driving through the rain
3. Close overhead view of people standing by side of road in the rain
4. Close overhead of children in the rain
5. Mid of people standing by a vehicle on a flooded street, one of them holding an umbrella
6. Mid of two people pushing a motorbike through floodwaters
7. Various of people pushing cars through floodwaters
8. Mid of boy sitting on motorbike as man wheels bike through flooded street
9. Mid of vehicles driving along flooded street
10. Close low shot of floodwaters falling into a drain
11. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) vox pop, Abdul Quddoos, Karachi resident:
"We are facing numerous problems as transport vanished from the streets. Roads are filled with rain water touching knee level. And families are suffering. No efforts were seen from the government to improve the situation. 
12. Mid of police officers standing knee deep in floodwaters, cars splashing through behind them
13. Mid of people and vehicles moving slowly through flooded street
14. Various of vehicles moving slowly in traffic jam on flooded street
15. Mid of hospital ward interior, pan left to people lying on hospital beds, man being treated
16. Mid of man lying on hospital bed being checked
17. Various of patients lying on beds, some with bandages
18. Wide of hospital exterior, with floodwaters in front of building
STORYLINE:
Monsoon rains which inundated the southern Pakistani city of Karachi on Saturday claimed at least nine lives and injured many more, hospital sources said. 
A police surgeon at the city''s Civil Hospital Dr Hamid Paryar told the Associated Press that they were electrocuted in rain related incidents.
Several injured bikers were rushed to different hospitals, as dozens of motorcycles skidded on slippery roads in various areas of the city.
Commuters were stuck in traffic jams for several hours and many vehicles ran out of petrol as heavy rain lashed Pakistan''s largest city. 
The rains in southern Pakistan began in early August 12 and have affected some 170,000 acres of agricultural land.
A Pakistani relief official said earlier this week the monsoon rains in the south of the country have killed 136 people.
Monsoon season in Pakistan usually lasts until the middle of September.

items.title: Flood displaced struggle in disaster zone, crops damaged
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Sick girl lying on table inside a makeshift camp set up at an educational institute in Tando Bago town
2. Pan of (women and children displaced by floods) inside a classroom
3. Mid shot woman carrying baby 
4. Various of flood victims sitting in corridor
5. SOUNDBITE (Sindhi) Bibi Mero, Flood Victim:
"We are not receiving any relief goods, even not a single five kilogram bag of flour. Now the government is telling us that we should get out from here, our houses have been inundated with floodwater. What can we do?"
6. Various of women washing dishes in dirty water and mud
7. Water being distributed to flood-affected people
8. People waiting to get water
9. Close of sign board, reading (English) "Government Monotechnic Institute of Tando Bago"
10. Various of flooded cotton field
11. Various of woman walking in flooded field
12. SOUNDBITE (Urdu) Ali Bakhs Shah, Local farmer:
"Our main cotton crop has been spoiled and 90 to 99 percent of our remaining seasonal rice crop has also been spoiled. The sugarcane crop which was ready for delivery to sugar mills has been 90 percent affected (by the floods), there might be some sugarcane left in some upper part of field, if they have been cultivated on higher grounds. The chili and onion have been totally spoiled, all crops are gone, even there is no grass left for cattle."
13. Various of flooded chili field
14. Close of rice plants in floodwater
15. Various of farmers in rice field
STORYLINE
More than 200 people have died, 200-thousand have been left homeless and 4.2 (m) million acres of agricultural land have been inundated, as heavy flooding spreads across Pakistan''s Sindh province.
The town of Tando Bago, in Badin district - the worst hit district around 200 kilometres (124 miles) from Karachi - is under several feet of water in places, making it impossible for residents to return to their homes.
Affected families in Tando Bago were given shelter in a makeshift camp set up at an educational institute.
Bibi Mero, a flood victim seeking shelter at the institute, complained that they were not receiving enough aid from the Pakistani government. 
"We are not receiving any relief goods, even not a single five kilogram bag of flour," she said.
The floods began early last month (August), but heavy rains have compounded them recently and hampered relief efforts.
Four-point-two (m) million acres of agricultural land has also been inundated, authorities said, devastating (m) millions of US dollars worth of crops.
Local farmers in the Sindh province are once again facing huge financial losses with rice, cotton and sugarcane crops ruined.
Last year, southern Pakistan was hardest hit by massive floods that swamped much of the country, killing 2,000 people.
The United Nations, meanwhile, is rushing food and tents to Pakistan after Islamabad formally asked for foreign assistance this weekend. 
Japan and China have also pledged relief goods or money, according to the Pakistan government. 
The United States said it had paid for food packages for 23-thousand families, and that its local partners would soon begin handing out tents, clean water and other supplies.
The return of the floods is testament to the heaviness of the monsoon rains that lash much of South Asia from June to September, as well as the limits of Pakistan''s weak and corrupt government.
As they did last year, the floods are undercutting the legitimacy of the shaky government, which is already widely disliked and struggling against Islamist militants, ever present political turmoil and massive economic problems.

STORYLINE
Monsoon rains are once more bringing misery to people in Pakistan.
The scale of the disaster is much smaller than it was last year, but that''s scant consolation for those affected -- officials say at least 200 people have died and 200,000 are homeless because of the high water in southern Sindh province.
The United Nations is rushing food and tents to the region after the government made a formal request for foreign assistance.
But help can''t come too soon for those who''ve sought shelter inside makeshift camps. Bibi Mero says nothing''s come her way yet...
SOT
even though the immediate crisis is acute, the disaster is more than a short-term problem in the country. The floods undercut the legitimacy of Pakistan''s shaky government, and with more than four million acres of agricultural land under water, there could be wider lasting economic consequences. Local farmer Ali Bakhs Shah 
SOT
Shah says the chili and onion fields have been spoiled as well, and there''s no grass left for the cattle, either.

Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: UN to continue aid following floods last year
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of news conference
2. Close of United Nations logo
3. SOUNDBITE (English) Rauf Engin Soysal, UN special envoy for assistance to Pakistan:
"We certainly need to do more, we certainly need to draw lessons, yet we certainly need to keep up the momentum to continue to deliver the promises we made one year ago to our brothers and sisters in Pakistan."
4. Cutaway of UN representatives
5. Wide of Soysal 
6. SOUNDBITE (English) Zafar Iqbal Qadir, chairman of Pakistan's National Disaster Management Authority:
"To the extent of providing proper housing to all the affectees, yes it has not been possible for the government so far, but that needs a huge amount of money which we still do not have at an our disposal."
7. UN officials at news conference
8. Wide of news conference
STORYLINE
The UN special envoy for assistance to Pakistan said on Thursday that more needs to be done to help those affected by last year's devastating floods.
The comments by Rauf Engin Soysal came as Pakistan marked the first anniversary of the country's worst ever floods that inundated a chunk of the country the size of the United Kingdom.
The flood that struck Pakistan in July 2010 represented one of the most devastating natural disaster of the decade, submerging almost one fifth of the country, killing 2000 people, affecting 20 (m) million and destroying 1.6 (m) million homes.   
Reconstruction is predicted to cost up to 10.9 (b) billion US dollars, almost one-quarter of Pakistan's national budget. 
It is unclear how Pakistan will come up with the money, and some flood victims complain that corruption has prevented them from benefiting from funds that are available.
Zafar Iqbal Qadir, chairman of Pakistan's National Disaster Management Authority, said that Pakistani government was willing to provide those who have been affected with "proper housing", however the government does not have the funds for their construction at this point.
The problem could get worse this year because Pakistan's threshold for coping with flooding is lower. 
Many of last year's victims are extremely vulnerable, and much of the flood infrastructure that was damaged, such as bunds and dikes, has not been repaired.

items.title: Floods in Karachi after heavy rain
items.description:
AP TELEVISION - AP CLIENTS ONLY

++DUSK SHOTS++
1. Tracking shot of people walking on flooded road 
2. Tracking shot of families on back of truck, moving away from flooding 
3. Tracking shot of people in flood waters
++DAY SHOTS++
4. People walking through food waters 
5. Group of men moving motorbike through flood waters
6. Various of tractors and trailers moving people away from flooding
7. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Mohammad Adnan, local resident: 
"Houses were inundated, vehicles turned over, home furniture, utensils and pets swept away. The shops were also badly affected and shops are under floodwaters. Refrigerators, freezers are lying outside shops, swept away. The situation is very bad. And there is no rescue. I have not seen them (rescue teams). They could not come as they haven't found a way to enter the affected areas."
8. Various of car half submerged by flood waters
9. Family watching flood waters 
10. SOUNDBITE: (Urdu) Noor Ali, local resident:
"No family has come out and they are trapped in their homes. No vehicles have entered the area for relief and rescue, so far.  Nothing has been done so far. Only a few youths from the area have managed to enter the flooded area. But no help has come from anywhere."
11. Car stuck in flood waters
12. Various of flooded roads
STORYLINE:
Heavy overnight rainfall in Karachi paralysed parts of the southern port city on Sunday morning and caused 14 deaths, according to local media reports.
The rains, which started on Saturday, turned into a heavy downpour that inundated several areas of Pakistan's largest city.
The deaths were caused by building collapses and electrocution, according to medical officials.
"Houses were inundated, vehicles turned over, home furniture, utensils and pets swept away," said one Karachi resident, Mohammad Adnan.
"The situation is very bad. And there is no rescue. I have not seen them (rescue teams). They could not come as they haven't found a way to enter the affected areas," he added.
Another resident, Noor Ali, said some families were trapped in their homes and still waiting for rescue officials.
Others were seen being moved by tractors and trailers away from the flooded areas. 
Forecasters have warned of more rains in Karachi and other parts of Pakistan.

items.title: Army uses helicopters to drop aid into severely flooded areas
items.description:
The Pakistani army on Sunday air-dropped relief supplies to villagers stranded by floodwaters in the Multan district of the eastern province of Punjab.
Military and civilian rescuers have been using helicopters and boats to evacuate people since 3 September, when monsoon rains triggered flooding.
"Our houses were inundated by floodwater four days ago. When a helicopter drops food, sometimes we get it - sometimes food is wasted," said Mohamamd Sadaqat, a resident of Multan district who had to abandon his home. 
Pakistan's disaster management agency said it would blow up another protective dike in an attempt to spare the city of Muzaffargagh.
Seventeen people were killed when a boat carrying a wedding party sank near the city of Multan. 
Separately, three people drowned in the same area overnight, according to rescue officials. 
The deaths, combined with those from the boat tragedy, brought the overall death toll from the flooding in Pakistan to 301.
The disaster management agency said the heavy rains and flooding had also injured more than 500 people in Pakistan and Pakistani-administered Kashmir, adding that more than two million people had been affected.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/1b6e352cfb96a0cddae8832d9a769447 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Soldiers come to the rescue of villagers stranded by floods
items.description:
With floods engulfing and devastating more districts in Pakistan's Punjab province, the country's army stepped up its rescue efforts on Monday to rescue stranded villagers.
The Pakistani army used boats to evacuate hundreds of marooned people from the country's plains where raging monsoon floods had inundated villages, leaving hundreds of thousands homeless. 
The floods were triggered by heavy monsoon rains at the beginning of the month and have so far claimed at least 500 lives, according to authorities.
In total nearly 300-thousand people have been evacuated from the flood-hit areas to over 200 relief camps set up by the army.


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/7e08dc0a58ba4715501d4aba623921cd 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Authorities evacuate residents from the flood devastated region of Punjab
items.description:
Pakistani authorities evacuated residents and animals from the flooded Jhang district in the Punjab region on Wednesday. 
Authorities said hundreds of thousands of people are fleeing flash floods after having been warned to evacuate as the death toll from severe monsoon rains in Pakistan and neighbouring India climbed to 457.
Rescue workers said they were concentrating on helping women, children and disabled people first, and would go back for the men who had managed to seek refuge by climbing onto rooftops. 
Evacuated villager, Halima Mai, whose grand-daughter was meant to be getting married said the dowry had been washed away along with her bedding and linen and that she had "lost everything".
Men could be seen standing in the floodwater with their livestock and on rooftops awaiting rescue. 
The Chenab River in the Jhang district breached an embankment early on Wednesday following a warning the day before, according to a spokesman for Pakistan's National Disaster Management Authority. 
He had said on Tuesday that the breach could cause nearly 700-thousand people to leave their homes.
Authorities in Pakistan say the floods, which began September 3, are the worst since massive flooding killed 1,700 people in 2010. 


You can license this story through AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/metadata/youtube/3d18546855275bb38a54a9fdf35b1cb7 
Find out more about AP Archive: http://www.aparchive.com/HowWeWork

items.title: Raging monsoon floods pour into the plains of eastern Punjab province
items.description:
Raging monsoon floods across India and Pakistan that have killed more than 450 people poured into the plains of eastern Punjab province on Wednesday, sending a major river pouring over its banks and threatening to force hundreds of thousands from their homes.
The Chenab River overflowed early on Wednesday, threatening the nearby Pakistani district of Jhang in the worst flooding in the region in years.
Thousands are now living in makeshift camps, whilst others continue to be evacuated from flood-hit areas.
The flooding began earlier this month in Kashmir, which is claimed by both India and Pakistan. 
It caused landslides and submerged much of Srinagar, the main city on the Indian-administered side. 
The water is now rushing out of the mountains of the Himalayan region, affecting communities downstream and threatening to force nearly 700-thousand people from their homes.
The rains have washed away houses, bridges, communication equipment and crops. 
There are now also health fears for some of the children who were rescued after the floodwaters had hit.
A doctor told Associated Press Television that he had seen children suffering from skin diseases and chest infections after playing in the waters.
In a statement, Pakistan's National Disaster Management Authority said that rescuers so far had evacuated more than 127-thousand people. 
It said civil authorities and troops were using 15 helicopters and 574 boats to move flood victims to safer places.
The floods are the worst to hit Pakistan since 2010, when some 1,700 people died. 
Authorities say they have alerted troops in Pakistan's southern Sindh province, where flooding was expected to reach later this week.
More than 1.5 (m) million people have been affected, with thousands losing their homes to the rising water.
At least 257 people have died and another 461 have been injured in Pakistan and Pakistan-administered Kashmir in the flooding, while 200 have been killed in India, officials say.

items.title: Pakistan-Occupied Kashmir Wants to be Part of India: Dehlavi
items.description: Kashmir, September 8, 2015: Distressed by growing extremism, lack of development and discriminatory policies of Islamabad, the people of Pakistan occupied Kashmir want to be a part of India, claimed Moulana Syed Athar Hussain Dehlavi, the chairman of the Anjuman Minhaj-e-Rasool. Distressed by growing extremism, lack of development and discriminatory policies of Islamabad, the people of Pakistan occupied Kashmir want to be a part of India, claimed Moulana Syed Athar Hussain Dehlavi, the chairman of the Anjuman Minhaj-e-Rasool. Dehlavi, who visited PoK after the devastating floods last year, said people there favour a referendum so that they can vote to join back to India. In September last year, when Pakistan Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif visited the flood-affected areas of PoK, he was greeted with slogans “Go Nawaz Go”. It reflected the frustration of the people with regard to the apathy of the Pakistan government in dealing with the very critical situation. The people in PoK are fed up with the atrocities committed against them by the Pakistani establishment for decades. The region has always been neglected by Islamabad and used for nurturing terror camps. The people of PoK are shocked after Pakistan signed more than 50 pacts worth an estimated USD 46 billion in infrastructure projects as part of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor. The corridor passed through Kashmir, will connect the city of Kashgar in western China with the Pakistani deep sea port of Gwadar.

items.title: 60 Dead in Colombia Mudslide
items.description: The death toll from the massive mudslide early Monday morning in the northwestern state of Antioquia has now topped 60. The heavy rains and mud have hampered rescue efforts and the exact number of victims is still unknown. A state of emergency has been declared in the village of Salgar. Also in Antioquia, demining operations have begun with the participation of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and specialists from other countries. In a major step forward for the peace process, the Colombian government, rebels, and the affected communities will work toger to rid the countryside of landmines. teleSUR http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/60-dead-in-colombia-mudslide/

items.title: Colombia: Landslides and Land Mines
items.description:
Rescue efforts are continuing in the village of Salgar, where residents were deluged with tons of mud and water on Monday, taking the lives of at least 60 people and injuring dozens. The worst natural disaster of its kind in more than a decade prompted President Juan Manuel Santos to declare a national emergency. As many as 48 people are still missing. Also in Colombia, a pilot project to clear land mines and explosive devices is underway in the state of Antioquia. An operation being carried out by the Colombian Army and the FARC guerrillas was agreed upon in the Havana peace talks. The first steps are being taken in the areas with the most victims. Out of 11,000 registered since 1999, as many as 2,500 are in Antioquia.  The pilot project consists of six stages, the first of which was the selection of the initial regions, and it is being followed by the Identification of the characteristics of the region. The deactivation and removal will be carried out by a special battalion of the army, accompanied by FARC rebels, who will show the troops where the land mines are located. Natalia Margarita reports from Colombia for teleSUR. 
 http://multimedia.telesurtv.net/v/colombia-landslides-and-land-mines/

items.title: Thousands Attend Colombia Mass Funeral
items.description:
For more WORLD NEWS "SUBSCRIBE" US

A mass funeral has taken place in the Colombian town of Salgar for victims of a devastating mudslide on Monday.
Burials were held for 33 of the 84 people whose bodies have been recovered. Several local people are still missing.
Thousands of people gathered in the square outside the town's main church to pay their respects in front of a long row of coffins.
Rescue workers are still searching the local river for victims.
One resident of Salgar particularly hard hit is the city's cemetery worker who has prepared 15 graves for members of his own family - mostly cousins who died in the flood.

A spokesman for the national emergency authorities said he expected to end the search for victims on Thursday or Friday.
He said between 20 and 25 local people caught in the flood had not been accounted for.
Locals and firefighters have been searching a 40km-long (25 mile) stretch of land on the banks of the Liboriana river.

items.title: Security preps ahead of President Bush arrival in Bogota
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of Bogota
2. Pan right of buildings
3. Mid of police standing with Bogota behind 
4. Close of weapon
5. Soldier talking on a phone attached to mobile unit being carried by a colleague 
6. Wide of soldiers, one talking on the phone 
7. Mid of police officers walking on the streets 
8. Mid of military commander Luis Eduardo Perez standing close to the Colombian flag 
9. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Luis Eduardo Perez, Army commander of the 13th military brigade:
"Right now Bogota, is in a state of calm. We can say that according to our intelligence work there are no reports of any actions or threats against Bogota."
10. Mid of man reading a newspaper with the picture of US President George W. Bush on the front
11. Close of newspaper with picture of Bush 
12. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Juan Carlos Rios, Resident of Bogota:
"Well, the best thing that the President of the United States, Mr. Bush can bring to Colombia is peace and goodwill to Colombians."
13. Various of newspapers featuring Bush
14 Street scene
15. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Cecilia Pulido, Resident of Bogota:
"I think that he (Referring to president Bush) is a good person. He has helped my family a lot.
Question: Why?
Answer: Because everything we have is thanks to him as well as the situation of my sons in the United States."
15. Wide of graffiti that reads in Spanish "Bush out of Colombia. Yankee go home" and people passing by 
16. Mid of graffiti reading in English "Yankee go home"
17. Mid of street and graffiti reading in Spanish "Bush out of Colombia".
STORYLINE:
Thousands of police officers and soldiers patrolled the streets of Bogota on Sunday, ahead of US President George W. Bush's arrival in Colombia on the latest leg of his Latin American tour.
Luis Eduardo Perez, Army commander of the 13th military brigade told AP Television on Sunday that Bogota was calm.
"We can say that according to our  intelligence work there are no reports of any actions or threats against  Bogota," he said.
Armed troops and military vehicles have been posted at checkpoints on the  city's roads, some 30-thousand soldiers and police were deployed to patrol the streets and helicopters could be seen high above country's capital, surveying the city of nearly seven (m) million from above.
Bogota residents who spoke to AP Television had mixed views about President Bush's visit.
"The best thing that the President of the United States, Mr. Bush can bring to Colombia is peace and goodwill to Colombians," said Juan Carlos Rios.
"I think that he (Referring to president Bush) is a good person. He has helped my family a lot," added Cecilia Pulido. "Everything we have is thanks to him as well as the situation of my sons in the United States."
Graffiti in Bogota was less complimentary about Mr. Bush, with messages written in both English and Spanish calling for the president to go home.  
Bush has been travelling to US-friendly Latin American nations to shore up relations and highlight US aid to the region.
His tour got underway in Brazil on Friday and he was due to visit Uruguay and  Guatemala before returning home to the US.
Bush was scheduled to arrive in Colombia at 1205pm local time (1705GMT).

items.title: 5 Afghans trained by Colombians in counter drug measures
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. US soldiers taking part in the training 
2. Soldiers marching 
3. Various of soldiers receiving instructions from commander   
4. Various of soldiers patrolling 
5. SOUNDBITE: (English) Sergeant Abdul Najid Haldary, Afghan Soldier:
"It's not easy. I came from so far, like from Asia, to here. I came here to work hard, not for resting. If I wanted to rest, I can rest in my home, in my country."
6. Translator interpreting questions for Afghan soldiers 
7. SOUNDBITE: (Farsi) Sergeant Muhammad Nouroz, Afghan soldier:
"I'm a Sergeant, I have been working with the police for two years specifically in counter narcotics."
8. Afghan soldiers patrolling 
9. Various of Afghan soldiers
STORYLINE
Members of Afghanistan's counter-narcotics police officers are being trained by their more experienced Colombian counterparts in the fight against drugs. 
The cooperation between the two countries was already in place, but for the first time the Afghan officers are now participating in the training, which is taking place on a police base in Ibague, the capital of the western Colombian department of Tolima, focuses mainly on finding and attacking drug labs. 
The Afghan officers, selected by their government to participate in the programme, are working very hard to learn as much as possible from their Colombian trainers.
"It's not easy. I came from so far, like from Asia to here. I came here to work hard, not for resting. If  I wanted to rest, I can rest in my home, in my country, said Sergeant Abdul Najid Haldary.
Afghanistan is currently struggling to control its drug trade, especially opium. 
An estimated 93 percent of the world's opium comes from Afghanistan, bringing in as much as 2 (b) billion US dollars (1.5 (b) billion euro) a year in profits.
Experts say booming profits from the lucrative crop are being used to fuel the Taliban. 
Colombia, on the other hand, has a long history of battling drug cartels.
The country remains remains the source of more than 90 percent of the world's cocaine, despite the recent unprecedented aerial fumigation of coca crops across the country.

items.title: Honduran President Zalaya visits, Uribe on economy
items.description:
1. Wide shot of Colombian President Alvaro Uribe, right, and President of Honduras Manuel Zelaya, left, walking together in the Presidential Palace of Narino
2. Wide of both presidents during the playing of national anthems 
3. Close of military band playing trumpets 
4. Wide zoom in to both presidents walking together 
5. Zelaya taking hat
6. Set up of Zelaya and Uribe at news conference 
7. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Alvaro Uribe, President of Colombia:
"One of the lessons that we have learned from the financial crisis in Wall Street is that the lack of regulation can stimulate that wild horse which is the speculative capital, and that can cause a lot of damage.  Countries have to be able to guarantee the productive capital, and we see that speculative capital only works against the interests of productive capital."
8. Cutaway of both presidents standing at news conference 
9. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Manuel Zelaya, President of Honduras: 
"We just concluded a meeting between the presidents of Central America, where we came up with several economic policies based on austerity in spending, and of greater investment, in order to give solvency to the banking system, the same as what President Uribe is doing here.  Also we want give solvency to the creation of new investments in the region.  Honduras is also consolidating public investment, not only private investment, in order to use commerce as a complement to social activities, which today represent one of our main challenges." 
10. Wide of both presidents walking into the Presidential Palace. 
STORYLINE: 
The President of Honduras Manuel Zelaya met his Colombian counterpart Alvaro Uribe in Bogota on Thursday, where the two discussed economic policies in light of the global financial crisis.
Speaking at a joint news conference outside the Presidential Palace of Narino, Zelaya said the pair had just concluded a meeting with other presidents of central America to discuss the situation.
Sporting his trademark stenson hat, Zelaya said the meeting would see the implementation of policies that would allow "greater investment" to give the regions' banking system solvency, while promising "austerity" in government spending.
Uribe said the "financial crisis in Wall Street" had showed that a lack of regulation in financial markets could have disastrous consequences.
Latin American stocks have been hard hit by the crisis, which has already forced intervention from the governments of Brazil, Mexico and Colombia.
Analysts say the region is worried a global recession could reduce demand for regional commodities such as metals, oil and agricultural goods.

items.title: WRAP New morgue shots, comments from French forensic team
items.description:
Maracaibo - 18 Aug 2005
1. Wide truck with forensic equipment arriving at morgue
2. Medium of truck
3. Various equipment on truck
4. Truck with morgue in background
5. Equipment
6. Police wearing masks standing guard 
7. Medium of police
8. French forensic expert
9. Press interviewing another French expert
10. Antonio Rivero at presser
11. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Antonio Rivero, National Civil Defence chief:
"Today, we''re going to finish the third phase, which means taking a pan of the entire area, approximately 100 metres from the impact, to determine whether any remaining human bodies or remains, as determined by the speed and impact of the plane." 
12. Cutaway press

Maracaibo - 18 Aug 2005
13. Various of delegation from Martinique arriving at morgue site 
14. SOUNDBITE (French) Pierre Fuedil, Vice President, General Council Martinique: 
"The relatives of the victims are going to arrive tomorrow at seven o''clock. (he pauses) They''re due at seven o''clock." Q: What do you think will happen tomorrow? "We represent the Martinique authorities and we want to make sure the families are well received. I hope we''ll be able to tell them what happened, that they will find out the truth." 
15. Delegation entering morgue  

STORYLINE:

Teams from France and from the island of Martinique continued their investigation in Venezuela on Thursday into the crash of a passenger jet that killed all 160 on board. 

The jet was carrying 152 passengers home from Panama to Martinique, a French overseas department in the Caribbean, when it crashed on Tuesday in Venezuela. 

Forensic experts and equipment used to identify victims'' bodies arrived from France at the University of Zulia medical school in the western Venezuelan city of Maracaibo, where the bodies are being held in a morgue. 

Eight Colombian crew members were also killed in the crash.

Col. Antonio Rivero, the chief of Venezuela''s emergency agency, said workers on Thursday were continuing to search for dead bodies and human remains at the crash site.

Colombia has grounded the airline that chartered the flight from Martinique while its civil air authority reviewed inspections that the small carrier had been required to perform.

Teams of French experts travelled to Venezuela to aid in the investigation and help identify victims'' remains, officials said. 

A strong odour of decaying bodies permeated the air outside the medical school morgue in Maracaibo where the bodies were being identified.

Three refrigerated shipping containers were placed outside for the remains to be loaded once identified.

Three men and a woman arrived from Martinique at the morgue accompanied by the French consul and hurried inside without speaking to journalists who crowded around them. They were said to be representatives of victims'' families, sent to help identify remains.

Authorities in Martinique also are to appoint two investigative judges to determine if anyone bears legal blame.

Venezuelan investigators were focusing on the possibility of contaminated fuel or some other fuel problem that led both engines to fail simultaneously, said a Venezuelan emergency official.

Panamanian authorities, however, said they found no evidence of tainted fuel and that the plane had plenty of fuel for the trip.

The pilot radioed the nearest airport before the crash, saying both engines had failed, and requested permission for an emergency landing.

Officials said the plane apparently fell into a steep descent minutes later.

items.title: President prepared to mediate an end to Colombia-FARC conflict
items.description:
25 June, 2010
1. Wide of Ecuadorean President Rafael Correa during interview
2. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador: 
"For any peaceful solution, non-violent, yes, count us in. If we can mediate, if we can serve as facilitators, count on us. It destroys our soul, the civil war that's been going on for so many decades, the absurd spilling of blood among brothers."
3. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
4. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador:
"Ecuador would like a clear answer, a clear apology from President Santos (Colombian President Elect Juan Manuel Santos) as president (Alvaro) Uribe has already done in order to get over this serious incident, because we can't 'try to cover the sun with one finger' and it is not that we look at the past bitterly, we look at the past with outrage. It was very serious what happened on March 1st 2008 and to normalise the relationship (between Colombia and Ecuador) we would like to clear this thing once and for all with a declaration (from the Colombian state) that this will not happen again."
5. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
6. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador:
"We won't take orders from anybody telling us with whom we can establish relationships or not."
(Q: Will you then strengthen the relationship with Iran?)
"Of course, as we will do with Russia, China, the US, Colombia or Venezuela.... with any country of the world with whom we can have bilateral relations based on mutual respect"
7. Cutaway of Correa being interviewed
8. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Rafael Correa, President of Ecuador: 
"We need our own forum to deal with our problems, without the unbalancing presence of the United States. The US is itself, 50 states. And nobody is questioning them being there or the existence of that unbalancing power but we need to discuss our things among equals, discuss realities closer to our realities, shared visions and so on and that's why we need our own institutions to solve the conflicts."
26 June, 2010
++QUALITY AS INCOMING++
9. Correa greeting Bolivian president Evo Morales, with Venezuelan president Hugo Chavez behind them 
10. Wide of main table with leaders of the ALBA group 
11. Close of Correa and Chavez talking 
12. Wide of gathering
13. Child giving Morales and Correa a flag, child hugging Correa 
12. Wide of meeting 
13. Child talking to Correa 
14. Pull out from statue of Simon Bolivar, hero of independence wars in Latin America, to wide of meeting
STORYLINE 
Ecuador's President Rafael Correa has said he would be happy to help mediate an end to Colombia's long-running conflict with leftist rebels, declaring on Friday that the conflict was an "absurd spilling of blood among brothers.".
He also said in an interview with The Associated Press Friday that he'd be pleased to attend the inauguration of Colombian President-elect Juan Manuel Santos next month, despite the fact that diplomatic ties between the two neighbouring countries have not been fully restored and he has not received any formal invitation.
Ecuador broke off relations with Colombia after its military crossed into Ecuador in March 2008 and attacked the jungle camp of top Colombian rebel leader Raul Reyes, killing him and 24 others in a pre-dawn raid.
An Ecuadorean judge last month issued an arrest warrant for Santos, who was Colombia's defence minister at the time.
Santos won the presidency by a landslide last Sunday with 69 percent of the vote. 
He has called the arrest warrant absurd because it was the Colombian state, not him as an individual, which made the cross-border incursion. 
He merely authorised it as defence minister, he said in an interview three days before his election.

items.title: SYND 1/5/80 DOMINICAN EMBASSY SEIGE ENDS IN BOGOTA
items.description:
The 61-day siege of the Dominican embassy in Bogota ended peacefully on Sunday(27 April) when the guerrillas of the M-19 group, plus 16 hostages, left the building for Eldorado airport. Four diplomats were released before the flight to Havana and full political asylum for the militants. Colombian officials said that the negotiated solution to the tense stalemate included a privately raised payment of two million dollars and the prompt release of all remaining hostages upon landing in Havana. The final settlement was arranged during meetings held between a petite, hooded woman guerrilla and government officials. A team led by Dr Tom Farer and representing the organisation of American states' human rights commission later served as a mediating force, guaranteeing that military trials of leftists still in Colombian prisons would be monitored by the OAS.

items.title: Peace comissioner anounces peace measures with FARC, analyst
items.description:
AP FILE
Unknown location - Undated 
1. Various of FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) troops 
Presidential VNR - No access Colombia
Bogota, 30 May 2006
2. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Luis Carlos Restrepo, Colombia's Peace Commissioner:
"Good afternoon everyone, this morning the President and his delegates met to explore the possibility of searching for new peace paths with the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia). The government will proceed with all its will and decency to make this happen. Bogota, May 30th 2006. Thank you very much."
3. Mid shot of Colombia's peace commissioner Luis Carlos Restrepo after reading the statement
AP FILE 
Unknown location - Undated 
4. Various of FARC troops 
AP Television 
Bogota, 30 May 2006
5. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Vicente Torrijos, Analyst and Political Scholar from the University del Rosario: 
"President Uribe will try to approach and see to what extent the FARC will agree to a cease fire or a modification of its radical behaviour to proceed to a humanitarian exchange (of the political hostages). But if President Uribe doesn't get any answers from them (in order to reach an agreement ) he will come off to be as obstinate and radical as he has been so far during his presidency and as radical as the FARC is." 
6. Mid shot of political analyst walking away after the interview
AP FILE
Unknown location - Undated 
7. Various of FARC troops 
STORYLINE:
Colombian peace commissioner Luis Carlos Restrepo met the newly re-elected President Alvaro Uribe 
after relatives of kidnap victims chided the newly re-elected leader for not mentioning their loved ones in his victory speech. 
Restrepo said in a statement Uribe wanted to "search for new peace paths with the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia," or FARC.
Uribe was re-elected Colombia's president after a landslide victory on Sunday in which he won 62 percent of the vote - 40 percent more than his nearest rival.
But in his 45-minute victory speech, Uribe failed to mention his strategy for bringing the leftist rebels to the negotiating table. 
Instead he focused on economic achievements like a free trade agreement reached with the United States.
The FARC is believe to hold more than 60 prominent hostages, including three American defence contractors captured when their small plane crashed into a FARC stronghold in the jungle in 2003.
A doubling of the defence budget and sharp increase in troop strength allowed the law-and-order Uribe to force the FARC to retreat into the jungle during his first term, helping to dramatically reduce what's still one of the world's highest kidnapping and murder rates.
Despite the military advances, most analysts believe it's impossible for the government to defeat the 15,000-strong guerrilla army on the battlefield. 
During the campaign, Uribe acknowledged the time for talks was approaching.
Analyst and political scholar from the University del Rosario, Vicente Torrijos said that " if President Uribe doesn't get any answers from them (in order to reach an agreement ) he will come off to be as obstinate and radical as he has been so far during his presidency and as radical as the FARC is." 
The FARC has resisted the government's peace attempts so far.
A few months ago, a proposal backed by France, Spain and Switzerland to exchange the hostages for FARC members held in prison failed to take off, with FARC leaders vowing they'd never strike a deal with Uribe.

items.title: Thousands of homes damaged in deadly floods
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Wide of flooded street in neighbourhood on the outskirts of Bogota
2. Residents being evacuated in an inflatable boat 
3. Emergency worker helping crying woman through floodwater after leaving her house 
4. Emergency workers carrying children from boat onto dry land 
5. SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) Sandra Patricia Salamanca, resident in flooded building:
"We have spent the last three days in the water, three days. They are telling us to evacuate, to leave the place but who is going to watch over the apartments that we are leaving behind?"
6. Flooded main street
7. Women carrying belongings out of their homes 
8. Partly submerged car 
9. Residents walking next to flooded apartment blocks 
10. More residents being evacuated by boat 
11. Wide of flooded area 
12. Police officers carrying resident's belongings through water  
13. Residents who live in upper floods returning to their homes, being dropped off by police boat  
14. Wide of flooded area 
STORYLINE
Flooding caused by heavy rains has forced the evacuation of at least 3,500 families from their homes on the outskirts of the Colombian capital, officials said.
Police officers and emergency workers helped dozens of families to leave their apartments in a neighbourhood south of Bogota on Thursday.
Those living in ground and first floor apartments were evacuated in boats provided by Bogota's emergency services.
Residents tried to take as many personal belongings with them as they could, but many refused to leave, fearing that their properties would be looted.
The second rainy season of the year has caused floods in various parts of northwest and central Colombia.
The rainfall has not been as intense as last year nor as bad as it was in early 2011, but the land still has not been able to absorb the extra water. 
There have also been several landslides in the region in the last 48 hours, which have damaged roads and blocked transit routes.
A hillside loosened by rain collapsed on a bus in northeastern Colombia killing at least three people, officials said.
A Red Cross rescue director said two other people were trapped in the bus late on Tuesday.
Officials say 105 people have died in flooding and landslides since the second rainy season began on September 1.
Colombia has two rainy seasons every year: the first one starts in March and ends in June, the second one lasts from September until December.

items.title: Police checking reports of computers stolen at Honduran embassy party
items.description:
SHOTLIST
1. Exterior of entrance of Honduras Embassy in Colombia: (Spanish) "Honduras Embassy."
2. Close of embassy sign at gate reading (Spanish) "Honduras Embassy."
3. Wide exteriors of Honduras embassy 
4. Wide exteriors of Bogota Metropolitan Police building
5. Mid of Colombian Police Col. Jose Elias Baquero talking to reporters
6. SOUNDBITE (Spanish) Col. Jose Elias Baquero, Colombian Police:
"Immediately (after finding out about stolen computers) police offered this government official (Jorge Mendoza, in charge of Honduran Embassy in Colombia) judicial services and the ability to make a complaint with the Bogota Metropolitan police, but this gentleman immediately declined to file a complaint with the police and said that this matter would be handled internally in the embassy."
7. Wide exteriors of embassy
8. Close of Honduran flag
STORYLINE
Colombian police say they are investigating reports that at least two computers were stolen during a party at the Honduran Embassy in Bogota that involved presumed
prostitutes.
Police Col. Jose Elias Baquero said police were searching for what he described as two "contracted women" who attended the 20 December party.
He says Honduran officials have confirmed that there was a party in which two laptop computers were stolen, but that they prefered to handle the matter internally.
According to Baquero after police were informed of an "abnormal situation" at the embassy, they made contact  with Jorge Mendoza, an official who is described as being "in charge at the time of the embassy."
Baquero says that Mendoza confirmed to police that there was a party during which two laptops were stolen. 
According to Baquero, Mendoza also said there were women hired to be at the party from a neighbourhood in northern Bogota known, among other things, for having many brothels.
Colombian police say they have drawn sketches of the presumed prostitutes, but Mendoza declined to make any identifications. 
Eight investigators have been assigned to the case. 
The embassy did not respond to repeated calls seeking comment and the Foreign Ministry in Tegucigalpa said it may release information later.

items.title: President VladimirPutin to add 40 ballistic missiles to nuclear arsenal /NATO denounces
items.description:
President VladimirPutin to add 40 ballistic missiles to nuclear arsenal /NATO denounces  'saber-rattling'
President VladimirPutin to add 40 ballistic missiles to nuclear arsenal /NATO denounces  'saber-rattling'
President VladimirPutin to add 40 ballistic missiles to nuclear arsenal /NATO denounces  'saber-rattling' |Devid news
KUBINKA, Russia (Reuters) - President Vladimir Putin said on Tuesday that Russia was concerned about an anti-missile defense system near its borders, after announcing that Russia would add more than 40 intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM) to its nuclear arsenal this year.

"We will be forced to aim our armed forces ... at those territories from where the threat comes," Putin said.

Putin made his comments a day after Russian officials denounced a U.S. plan to station tanks and heavy weapons in NATO member states on Russia's border. Putin said it was the most aggressive act by Washington since the Cold War a generation ago.

U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concern over Putin's missile announcement and said no one wanted to see backsliding "to a kind of a Cold War status."

items.title: Permafrost Snow of Lake Baikal in June
items.description:
Free video about permafrost layer. This free video was created for you by http://epsos.de and can be used for free under the creative commons license with the attribution of epSos.de as the original author of this permafrost layer video.

The permafrost is the layer of ice permanently on the surface levels of the floor of the very cold regions or glacial, such as the tundra. It can be found in circumpolar areas of Canada, Alaska, Siberia, Tibet, Norway and in several islands of the Atlantic Ocean south as South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands. We have also found this phenomenon on the surface of Mars. Permafrost can be divided into permafrost, the frozen layer deeper, outermost layer usually thaw. For hundreds of thousands of years, the Arctic permafrost has accumulated large reserves of organic carbon.

Permafrost form where the annual average temperature is -1 ° C and the annual precipitation does not exceed 1000 mm. Thus, the large permafrost areas in the world are in the polar regions to the Arctic and Antarctic tundra, in large parts of the boreal forest areas, but also in all areas which meet the conditions for permafrost, such as high mountains. As permafrost zone is called "the circumpolar region eternal frozen ground, the tundra of northern continents, the large forest areas and offshore areas of the seabed.

Geographically, there are large parts of northern Canada, Alaska, Greenland and Eastern Siberia. Approximately 20 to 25% of the land area of the earth is permafrost, and Greenland to 99%, Alaska at 80%, Russia 50%, Canada up to 20% are 40 to 50% and China from permafrost. Permafrost areas is also available in high mountain regions such as the Alps. You are the last ice age, when the ground froze places up in several 1000 meters depth. In addition to these fossil permafrost areas in the Alps will take place today - albeit very limited - even recent permafrost formation instead.

In addition, there are also submarine permafrost, so permafrost at the bottom of the seas. By density anomaly of the water actually physically impossible to explain this as follows: by the static sea level variation in the last ice age were many continental shelves, which are now back under water, above sea level, making the soil up to several 100 meters depth were able to develop permafrost. 

In the wake of global warming a northward migration in recent decades has been the permafrost in North America and to a lesser extent in Eurasia observed. The consequences are damage to roads and houses, now where the permafrost thaws only on morass stand. Moreover, in this case in permafrost-bound large amounts of methane into the atmosphere from escaping. This process would be a strengthening of the warming since the global warming potential of methane is about 25 times as large as that of CO 2.

The thawing of permafrost makes short term and locally for already significant and threatening changes in topography. In areas with permafrost therefore buildings are built primarily on stilts that reach down into the permanently frozen areas of the soil and thus stand on firm ground. A geothermal -use heat pump heating can cause an artificial permafrost if the withdrawn heat energy can no longer be adequately replenished by the environment. In this case forms around the heat exchanger coils in the ground a block of frozen ground, which significantly reduces the heating power.

The layer or thaws and freezes again, the active layer mentioned. In the active layer can grow plants in the permafrost layer is not. The thickness of the active layer depends on the weather and changes with the years, but it is usually between 60 and 360 cm. The thickness of the permafrost could amount to tens of meters (at Barrow in Alaska was once measured more than 400 meters). Except to the mainland, permafrost also for Antarctic and Arctic islands like Bouvet Island.

A major city that is built on the permafrost is the Russian city Yakutsk in northeastern Siberia with more than 200,000 inhabitants. The average annual temperature is around -9. The permafrost layer is according to locally obtained data (the Permafrost Institute, July 2010) is approximately 300 meters thick.

Measurement of the depth and extension of the permafrost could be a clue to study the greenhouse effect can be and in recent times (1999 and 2001) records are established for the thawing of permafrost in Alaska and Siberia. Accurate data, however, collected only since circa 1970, so that no final conclusions can be drawn.

items.title: Centcom, Russian reax as diplomats come under fire during Baghdad evacuation
items.description:
APTN
Moscow, Russia -  April 6, 2003
1. Exteriors Ministry of Foreign Affairs building  
2. US Ambassador Alexander Vershbow leaving the building 
3. Cutaway Ministry of Foreign Affairs sign
4. SOUNDBITE (English) Alexander Vershbow, US Ambassador to Russia: 
"We still are gathering the information about the incident that took place a few hours ago. We are obviously very concerned about those who have been wounded. We still do not know which forces were involved, we don't know anything about the circumstances of the incident, but I undertook to get more information from our commanders and to share immediately with the minister, with the Russian government."      
5. Cutaway press
6. SOUNDBITE (English) Alexander Vershbow, US Ambassador to Russia: 
"It is very difficult situation, it is a war zone. We did coordinate with the Russian side on this departure but Iraqi forces are active and there are many military exchanges  going on but we will do as much as we can to facilitate their safe departure."
7. Vershbow gets into his limo, leaving

POOL
Central Command
Doha, Qatar -  April 6, 2003
8. Wide shot CENTCOM briefing
9. Mid shot  reporter asking a question
10. SOUNDBITE (English) Brigadier General Vincent Brooks, deputy director of operations:
"We have some initial reports from are embassy in Russia that there may have been some sort of accident that occurred with respect to that set of vehicles leaving Iraq. We were aware of them leaving Iraq, we certainly had information about that and  an anticipation of how they might move and with that  we wanted to ensure were providing as much protection as we could.  We don't know the circumstances surrounding this or even the factual basis of it yet, we understand they are still moving at this point in time and as we get more information, we absolutely want to get to the bottom of  that particualry report. We don't have any specifics yet. We understand that this group of vehicles is still moving."

APTN File. 
Baghdad -  Recent
11. Exteriors of Russian embassy

STORYLINE:

A convoy of Russian diplomats, including the ambassador to Iraq, came under fire on Sunday as they were evacuating from Baghdad, the Kremlin said. 

The vehicles came under fire as they were moving towards the Syrian border and several people were wounded, said the Russian Foreign Ministry.

Russian officials had long ago evacuated most of the embassy's staff, but a core team had remained until Sunday, including the ambassador.

President Vladimir Putin has been informed about the incident, the Kremlin press service said.

The Foreign Ministry said it urgently called in the U.S. and Iraqi ambassadors and asked them to take all measures necessary to guarantee Russian citizens' safety in Iraq, to investigate the circumstances of the attack and punish those responsible.

The ministry said there were wounded but had no information on how many. 

As he left the Foreign Ministry building, Ambassador Alexander Vershbow said the U.S. government was investigating the incident and trying to gather information from allied commanders in the area. He said the U.S. side would do its best to expedite the diplomats' evacuation.

Vershbow confirmed that the United States had been aware of the planned evacuation ahead of time.

At Central Command, Vincent Brooks, deputy director of operations, said details were unclear but they wanted to, "absolutely get to the bottom" of the reports.

On Wednesday, Russia protested against American airstrikes that allegedly targeted a Baghdad neighbourhood where the Russian Embassy was located. Russia did not report any casualties in connection with the strikes.

items.title: Russia-How Kremlin's Special Soldiers Are Trained
items.description:
T/I 10:21:14


HOW KREMLIN'S SPECIAL SOLDIERS ARE TRAINED

Russia          Natural Sound          Duration: 2.08"

The Tamanskaya special division of the Russian army, the Kremlin's
own crack forces, recently opened its doors for a rare glimpse of
its military training exercises. Located 60 kilometers west of
Moscow, the Tamanskaya division has some of the best-trained and
best-equipped troops in the Russian armed forces. Other army
divisions have to cope with shortages of coal, food, bullets and
other crucial supplies, but the Tamanskaya troops are relatively
well off. The Tamanskaya division is known for being an arm of the
government. More than once it has come to the Kremlin's rescue.
During the August 1991 attempt to overthrow Soviet leader Mikhail
Gorbachev, Tamanskaya troops surrounded Russia's White House in
Moscow in a symbolic move to demonstrate their loyalty. They were
called into Moscow again in October 1993 and refused to use their
weapons to bring down President Boris Yeltsin. Public attention is
once again turning to the Tamanskaya division in view of the
approaching presidential elections in June. There is speculation
that Yeltsin might call off the election if his chances of
emerging victorious appear threatened. Should the opposition
decide to challenge a cancellation, the Tamanskaya division would
likely play a crucial role.


SHOWS: 

(RUSSIA) 

Snow-covered military training field west of Moscow. Army tanks rolling by. Tank. Young Russian soldiers in the Tamanskaya division during training exercises. Anti-aircraft weapon. Artillery fire. Army officers gathered at command point.
Tank firing its cannon. Soldier firing a rocket-propelled grenade.
Soldier running up to gun, throwing himself flat on ground and
firing his weapon. Pan across field to distant explosion. Exchange
of gunfire. Explosion across field. Officers gathered under tent
at command point. Commander Vyacheslav Borisov giving orders over
short wave radio. Explosions. Tank. Soldiers standing in line.
Young soldier's face. SOT Commander Borisov in Russia, saying
"We're going to capitalise on our experience in Chechnya and also
Afghanistan to create a new, special, mobile force. We're
currently working on special preparations and military exercises
for this programme."

KGB AGENTS FIND NEW ROLE IN LIFE - AND DEATH

Crime and assassination have turned the Russia's bodyguard industry into big business. Over the past three years several Russian bank managers, businessmen, deputies and journalists have been murdered. Not only stars or politicians need a bodyguard, but businessmen as well. One of the Western clients is Frank M. Brentnell, president of The American Russian Foundation. He admitted that for him security was one of the most important issues when in Moscow. Women are also muscling into the market and they are working on a new concept, the "secretary-bodyguard". Even veteran Soviet spies from the KGB have redefined themselves in the security business.

items.title: Army RUSSIA
items.description:
►►► Russian Troops on FULL ALERT ◄◄◄
READY for BIGGEST MILITARY DRILL "Troops on FULL ALERT" | Defense |
"Russian Army Goes East With BIGGEST 2014 WAR DRILL"

MOSCOW, November 30, 2013 

The Russian military will hold its biggest drill of 2014 in the country's east, First Deputy Defense Minister Arkady Bakhin said Saturday.

The East-2014 exercise will involve several army branches, Bakhin said on Ekho Moskvy radio.

He did not elaborate on the program or the exact time and venue for the event.

This year's biggest drill, West-2013, took place in the Russian western exclave of Kaliningrad and the neighboring Belarus, Russia's major European ally.

The Russian army held about 3,000 drills in 2013, including some 400 involving multiple army branches, Bakhin said.

Russia has 29 international military exercises lined up for next year, Bakhin also said.

Moscow announced last week plans to hold joint drills with China and Mongolia in 2014.


•••

& Russia Plans to Have 4 'Massive' Military Training Ranges...

Each of Russia's four military districts will have its own training range capable of hosting large-scale exercises involving all branches of the armed forces, a senior defense official said Saturday.

First Deputy Defense Minister, Gen. Arkady Bakhin, said in an interview with Echo Moskvy radio that the first such training range, dubbed Mulino, is being constructed in the Nizhny Novgorod region for the Western Military District.

According to Bakhin, construction of the Mulino training range is expected to be completed in summer next year.

"A contract for the construction of the second range, based on the Ashuluk training facility in the Southern Military District, has been signed," Bakhin said.

Its size and advanced equipment will allow the Defense Ministry to train and inspect combat capabilities of large military units, including entire armies, the official said.

The third training range will be built near the town of Tsugol in Siberia for the Eastern Military District, while the site for the training facility in the Central Military District has not yet been determined, the general said.
•••MOSCOW, November 30, 2013 (RIA Novosti)••• 

• Archive VIDEO , *West-81/Запад-81: code name for strategic exercises of the army and navy of the USSR and the Warsaw Pact , held from 4 to 12 September 1981 on the territory of Belarus , the Baltic and the Kiev military district , as well as in the Baltic Sea. In addition to the Soviet Union , the exercises were also carried out on the territory of several friendly countries .
(West-81: the largest strategic exercises in the history of the Soviet Armed Forces. On a scale comparable only with the major operations of the Great Patriotic War. During the exercise, "West 81 " were first tested the automated control system and some types of high-precision weapons.)

items.title: Britain, France sign deal to step up joint security operations at Eurotunnel
items.description:
Britain and France announced new measures on Thursday (August 20) to prevent undocumented migrants entering the Channel Tunnel, while stepping up joint police operations against the people-smugglers who profit from their desperation to reach Britain.

Both countries will contribute police resources to a shared "command and control" centre in the northern French port city of Calais, Britain's Home Office said in a statement.

The new joint command will "find and disrupt organised criminals who attempt to smuggle migrants into northern France and across the Channel", it said.

For Britain and France, Calais is the focus of a wider migration crisis fuelled by conflict, persecution and poverty that has sent hundreds of thousands out of Syria, Libya and other Middle Eastern and African states.

Tens of thousands of migrants are arriving in Italy and Greece each week, while Germany expects the number of asylum applications to quadruple to a record 800,000 this year, the government said on Wednesday.

Thousands of migrants are holed up in makeshift encampments in Calais, with many trying each night to jump onto trucks or trains, or even walk the 31-mile (50-km) undersea tunnel to Britain. Some are killed in the attempt.

Led by senior French and British police commanders, the new centre will report to both interior ministers.

New measures include increased French police numbers and British-funded fencing, CCTV and other security equipment to protect the tunnel entrance in Calais, the Home Office said.

Operator Eurotunnel (GETP.PA) will receive unspecified "support" to deploy more security guards at the site, it added.

The growing refugee crisis will also feature in talks between French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel on Monday, as southern European states bearing the brunt of the influx press for a concerted EU-wide response.

France wants to set up processing centres for speedier treatment of asylum applications at Europe's main entry points and use development policy to enlist better cooperation from transit countries, Fabius said.

items.title: Suspected grenade thrower caught on camera in Kiev
items.description:
Footage released by Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty on Monday (August 31) appears to show a suspect hurling a grenade which killed one and injured nearly 90 outside Ukraine's parliament.

A Ukrainian national guardsman died on Monday (August 31) during violent protests outside parliament in Kiev, as lawmakers voted to give more autonomy to rebel-held areas in the east of the country.

Interior Minister Arsen Avakov said in a tweet that nearly 90 national guardsmen had been hurt, four of them with serious wounds to the eyes, stomach, neck and legs, by several explosive devices that were lobbed at them from crowds massed outside.

National guardsmen and police officers were seen attending to the wounded amid clouds of tear gas. Puddles of blood and discarded equipment were strewn on the ground.

The violence came after the deputies voted by 265 in favour of the first reading of the bill - 39 more than that required to pass - at a boisterous session with many deputies shouting "Shame!" and rhythmically beating parliamentary benches.

items.title: Shamanism Rituals in Russia
items.description:
Free video about Shamanism. This video was created for you by http://epsos.de and can be re-used for free under the creative commons license with the attribution of epSos.de as the original author of this Shamanism video.

Thank you for supporting the creative commons movement !!

The Shamanism refers to a class of traditional beliefs and practices similar to animism that ensure the ability to diagnose and cure human suffering. A second group of anthropologists discussed the term shamanism, saying it is a word for a specific cultural institution, to include any healer of any traditional society, it produces a false uniformity between these cultures and creates the misleading idea of the existence of a religion before all others. Others accuse them of being unable to recognize the commonalities between the various traditional societies.

Shamanism is based on the premise that the visible world is pervaded by invisible forces and spirits of parallel dimensions that coexist simultaneously with ours, affecting all the manifestations of life. In contrast to animism, in which every member of society involved the practice, shamanism requires specialized knowledge or skills.

There are many variations of shamanism in the world; the following are shared by all forms of shamanism beliefs: 1 -there clarify that comes from shamanism "shaman", who is typical of eastern Siberia, though, as Mircea Eliade notes in his attempt to make a general history shamanism, there are a variety of shamans scattered around the world, and characterizes them being medical and spiritual guides.

Shamanism is based on the premise that the visible world is pervaded by invisible forces or spirits that affect the lives of the living. Unlike organized religions such as animism or animatism that are led by pastors and that all members of a society practice, shamanism requires individualized knowledge and special abilities. Shamans act outside established religions, and traditionally act alone. Shamans can come together in associations, as have practitioners Tantric Indians.

According to Kehoe, Eliade Shamanism is an invention synthesized from various sources unsupported by any direct research. Believes that what he and other scholars define as characteristic of shamanism, trances, chants, communication with spirits, cures, are practices that exist in shamanic cultures do not like some Judeo-Christian rituals. In your opinion, they are typical of many cultures that use them, and you can not include in a religion -call shamanism. Therefore, it rejects that shamanism is an ancient surviving religion of Palaeolithic.

This may not only reveal the visions animist hiding behind shamanism, but also express their relevance to the recent world where ecological problems do paradigms valid balance and protection. Just as shamanism itself, music and songs related to it in various cultures are diverse, far from being similar. In some cultures and in some cases, some songs related to shamanism also try to imitate natural sounds, sometimes through onomatopoeia.

Shamanism is considered by some to be the history of all organized religions, since it was born before the Neolithic. The pagan Greek was influenced by shamanism, as reflected in the stories of Tantalus, Prometheus, Medea and Calipso among others, as well as the mysteries, like those of Eleusis. Some of the shamanic practices of the Greek religion were copied later by religion of Romans.

Today, shamanism survives mainly in indigenous peoples. His practice continues in the tundras, jungles, deserts and other rural areas, and also in cities, towns, suburbs, and villages around the world. It is particularly widespread in Africa, and also in South America, where there is called "shamanism mestizo ".

Although shamanism had a great tradition in Europe before the advent of monotheism, remained as a traditional organized religion only in Mari-El and Udmurtia, two semi-autonomous provinces of Russia. Siberia is a center of shamanism, inhabited by many different peoples. Many of the people who populate the Urals and Altai, have maintained these practices alive until modern times. Many of the ethnographic sources have been collected from people. Many groups of hunters and breeders of reindeer practiced shamanism as a living tradition also in modern times, especially those who have lived isolated until recent times as naganasan.

Shamanism is still practiced in South Korea, where the role of women represent shaman calls mudang, while few men are known as baksoo mudang. Both are usually members of lower classes. There is a great influence on the shamanic religion of Bon central Asia, and in Buddhism Tibetan ; Buddhism became popular among Tibetan shamans, Mongols, and Manchus in the early eighth century.
